This civil rights activist, co-founder of the National Farm Workers Association (later the United Farm Workers), organized grape boycotts and hunger strikes to protest the working conditions of farmworkers. A strong believer in nonviolence, he often employed fasting as a means of protest. Who is this iconic figure in American labor history who is celebrated with a federal holiday on March 31 each year?

This medical drama, set in Seattle, Washington, follows the lives of surgical interns, residents, and attendings as they navigate personal and professional challenges. Its first episode aired in 2005 as a mid-season replacement, and it has since become one of the longest-running primetime medical dramas in American television history. The show's title is a play on words, referencing both the main character's name and a classic anatomy textbook. What is this show known for its dramatic twists, love triangles, and heartbreaking departures?

The President of this American University resigned amid controversy after being accused of plagiarism in her academic work. This came after the president, Claudine Gay, testified in front on Congress on the campus's response to accusations of anti-semitism. The hearing led to the resignation of another university presidenty, Liz Magill, from University of Pennsylvania. This university is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and it is part of the historic Ivy League. Name this university, the oldest in the United States.

This NBA team, holding the league's record for the most consecutive three-pointers made in a game at 27, boasts two NBA championships, won in the mid-1990s. Led by legendary center Hakeem Olajuwon during their championship runs, they were known for their "Clutch City" resilience. Their home court, the Toyota Center, is a state-of-the-art arena located in downtown Houston. What is the name of this team, whose red and white color scheme pays homage to the city's aerospace industry?

This dystopian novel, set in a totalitarian theocracy where fertile women are forced into sexual servitude, is narrated by Offred, whose name reflects her status as property of the Commander. The story unfolds in Gilead, a former United States where environmental pollution and declining birth rates have led to extreme social and religious control. The novel's color-coded clothing system, where Handmaids wear red, Wives wear blue, and Aunts wear brown, symbolizes the rigid social hierarchy. What is the title of this novel by Margaret Atwood?

This physicist, born in Vienna, Austria, taught at several universities throughout Europe and eventually became the director of the School of Theoretical Physics at the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies. He shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 with Paul Dirac. His namesake equation describes the wave function of a quantum-mechanical system, is also known for a thought experiment involving a cat in a box, illustrating the concept of quantum superposition. Who is this key figure in the development of quantum mechanics?

Named after a Danish explorer in Russian service, this sea is home to a diverse array of marine life, including walruses, seals, and numerous whale species. It is also an important fishing ground, with large populations of salmon, pollock, and crab. This sea is known for its harsh weather conditions, with frequent storms and high winds. It separates the continents of Asia and North America, with a namesake strait connecting it to the Arctic Ocean. What is the name of this marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean?

This neurologist, who fled Vienna in 1938 due to the Nazi annexation of Austria, is famous for his groundbreaking theories on the unconscious mind and the development of psychoanalysis. His work explored concepts like the id, ego, and superego, and his "Interpretation of Dreams" remains a seminal text in psychology. He also introduced the concept of defense mechanisms, such as repression and denial, and his ideas continue to influence fields like psychology, literature, and art. Who is this influential figure?

This artist's most famous work, "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," showcases his meticulous technique of applying tiny dots of color to create a vibrant and shimmering effect. He developed this technique, known as pointillism, as part of the Neo-Impressionist movement. Despite his tragically short career, cut short by an early death at age 31, his innovative approach to color and light has had a lasting impact on the art world. Who is this influential French artist?

This first-person shooter franchise, originally focused on World War II settings, has since expanded to include modern and futuristic warfare scenarios. It is known for its fast-paced multiplayer mode and its immersive single-player campaigns. The series has spawned numerous spin-offs and has become one of the best-selling video game franchises of all time. What is the name of this popular military-themed video game series?

This rebel militia launched a drone attack against Tel Aviv, Israel which killed at least one person. Israel then responded by bombing parts Yemen controlled by this rebel group. The primarily Zaidi Shia Muslim group, named after its founder, has been engaged in a protracted conflict in Yemen since 2014. They control the capital Sana'a and much of the northern highlands. They are supported by Iran and have launched numerous missile and drone attacks against Saudi Arabia as well as container ships entering the Red Sea. What is the name of this Yemeni rebel group?

This country achieved independence on August 15, 1947, following a long struggle marked by nonviolent resistance. The independence movement saw widespread civil disobedience, including the Salt March, a protest against the British salt monopoly. The newly independent nation adopted a secular constitution, guaranteeing religious freedom for its diverse population. This country, once known as the "Jewel in the Crown" of the British Empire, is now the world's largest democracy. What is this country whose resistance was led by figures like Mahatma Gandhi?

This standoff, precipitated by the covert deployment of Soviet ballistic missiles, involved a U.S. naval blockade to prevent further shipments of military supplies. The situation escalated as both superpowers prepared for potential military action. Ultimately, a secret agreement was reached: the Soviet Union would dismantle its missiles in exchange for a U.S. pledge not to invade Cuba and the removal of American Jupiter missiles from Turkey. What is the name of this 13-day confrontation that brought the world to the brink of nuclear war?

This natural wonder, visible from outer space, is actually composed of over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands, stretching for 2,300 kilometers (1,400 miles). Home to over 1,500 species of fish, 411 types of hard coral, and one-third of the world's soft corals, it is the world's largest coral reef system. What is this iconic landmark, located off the coast of Queensland, Australia?

This element, discovered by Humphry Davy in 1808 through electrolysis, is essential for the formation and maintenance of bones and teeth. In its pure form, it is a soft, silvery-white metal that readily reacts with water and air. It plays a crucial role in muscle contraction, nerve transmission, and blood clotting. Found abundantly in dairy products, leafy green vegetables, and certain types of fish, it is the most abundant mineral in the human body. What is this element, with an atomic number of 20?

This team, originally established in New Orleans in 1974, relocated to Salt Lake City in 1979. Their iconic purple mountain logo symbolizes the majestic landscape of their home state. They reached the NBA Finals twice in the late 1990s, led by legendary duo John Stockton and Karl Malone. Despite never winning a championship, they are known for their passionate fan base and their high-altitude home court, the Vivint Arena. What is the name of this team?

This civilization's Old Kingdom period, characterized by political stability and economic prosperity, saw the construction of one of the wonders of the ancient world. This period is also known for the development of hieroglyphic writing, a complex system of pictograms and phonetic symbols used to record religious texts, historical events, and everyday life. The society was highly centralized, with the pharaoh considered a living god and holding absolute power. What is this ancient civilization located along the Nile River?

This science fiction horror film, set aboard a commercial spaceship in the distant future, features a creature designed by Swiss artist H.R. Giger. Its tagline, "In space, no one can hear you scream," became iconic. The film's protagonist, Ellen Ripley, was a groundbreaking female action hero who survived encounters with the deadly xenomorph. What is the title of this 1979 Ridley Scott film that spawned a successful franchise?

This artist's vibrant and dynamic paintings, such as "The Raising of the Cross" and "The Descent from the Cross," are characterized by their rich colors, dramatic lighting, and swirling compositions. He was a master of the Baroque style, known for his depiction of religious and mythological scenes, as well as portraits and landscapes. He was also a diplomat, serving as an envoy for the rulers of the Spanish Netherlands. Who is this influential Flemish artist?

This hilly city, built on seven hills overlooking the Tagus River, is famous for its colorful tiled facades, melancholic fado music, and iconic yellow trams. It is the westernmost capital city in mainland Europe and is known for its mild climate and stunning views. Rebuilt after a devastating earthquake in 1755, it boasts a unique blend of architectural styles, from Gothic and Manueline to Baroque and Neoclassical. What is this charming city, the capital of Portugal?

This lawyer, known for his sharp wit and brilliant legal mind, argued 32 cases before the Supreme Court and won 29 of them. He served as the chief counsel for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, where he played a pivotal role in dismantling segregation in the landmark Brown v. Board of Education case. In 1967, he became the first African American to be appointed to the Supreme Court, serving for 24 years until his retirement in 1991. Who is this groundbreaking figure in American legal history?

This movement, founded by Tarana Burke in 2006, gained widespread attention in 2017 following allegations of sexual misconduct against film producer Harvey Weinstein. It has since become a global phenomenon, empowering survivors to share their stories and holding perpetrators accountable. It has sparked conversations about power dynamics, consent, and the prevalence of sexual harassment and assault in various industries. What is the name of this movement that has empowered survivors and sparked a cultural reckoning?

This NBA team, founded in 1970 as an expansion team, play their home games at Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse, which they share with the Monsters of the American Hockey League. They experienced a period of dominance in the mid-2010s led by LeBron James, Kyrie Irving, and Kevin Love, culminating in their first NBA championship in 2016. What is this team, known for its wine and gold color scheme?

Once a popular ingredient in Victorian-era cosmetics and wallpapers due to its vibrant green pigment, this element is now known for its toxicity and association with poisoning. It is a metalloid found in the Earth's crust and can contaminate groundwater. In small doses, it was historically used as a medicine, but prolonged exposure can lead to various health problems, including skin lesions and cancer. What is this element, represented by the symbol As on the periodic table?

This neo-noir psychological thriller follows Leonard Shelby, a man suffering from anterograde amnesia, who uses tattoos, Polaroid photos, and notes to investigate his wife's murder. The film's narrative unfolds in a non-linear fashion, with scenes presented in reverse chronological order, mirroring the protagonist's fragmented memory. What is the title of this 2000 film directed by Christopher Nolan?
incorrect2: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind

question: On July 21, 2024, this politician was endorsed by President Joe Biden to be his party's nominee for the 2024 US presidential election. This politician was born in Oakland, California and rose through the ranks in California politics starting as a prosecutor. In 2016, she became the second African-American woman and the first South Asian American to serve in the U.S. Senate. She ran for president in 2020 but withdrew before primary voting began. Name this woman who became the first female vice president in US history in 2020.

This physicist's work on black-body radiation led to the development of a revolutionary theory that proposed energy is emitted and absorbed in discrete units, or "quanta." He received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918 for his discovery of energy quanta. His constant, denoted by the symbol 'h', is a fundamental constant of nature that relates the energy of a photon to its frequency. He is considered one of the founders of quantum mechanics. Who is this groundbreaking physicist?

This gymnast, nicknamed the "Flying Squirrel," made history as the first African-American to win the Olympic individual all-around title. She also led the U.S. women's gymnastics team, dubbed the "Fierce Five," to gold at the 2012 London Olympics. In 2016, she became the first reigning Olympic all-around champion to return to compete in a subsequent Olympics since Nadia Comăneci in 1980. Who is this accomplished American gymnast?

This explorer's initial voyage to India, lasting over ten months, encountered storms, scurvy, and hostile rulers along the African coast. His fleet consisted of four ships, including the flagship São Gabriel. His arrival in Calicut, India, in 1498, opened up a direct maritime route from Europe to Asia, bypassing the traditional land routes controlled by Arab traders. He later served as the Portuguese viceroy of India and died in Kochi in 1524. Who is this pioneering figure in European exploration?

Home to the Irrawaddy River, the country's most important commercial waterway, this Southeast Asian nation also boasts the world's largest book, housed in the Kuthodaw Pagoda. It is bordered by India, Bangladesh, China, Laos, and Thailand. This country is also home to the ancient city of Bagan, which boasts over 2,000 Buddhist temples and pagodas. What is this country which was once known as Burma?

This educator secretly funded legal challenges to segregation laws while publicly advocating for a gradual approach to racial equality. Born into slavery in Virginia, he became a leading voice for vocational education for African Americans. He founded the Tuskegee Institute, a school that emphasized practical skills and self-reliance. His autobiography, "Up from Slavery," chronicled his remarkable journey from bondage to prominence. Who is this influential figure in African-American history?

Painted in 1942, this painting captures the mood of urban alienation in wartime America. The artist, inspired by a diner he saw in Greenwich Village, New York City, used his wife and himself as models for two of the figures. The painting, depicting a late-night diner scene with four solitary figures, is known for its stark contrast of light and shadow, creating a sense of isolation and loneliness. What is the title of this famous work by Edward Hopper?

This sitcom, the highest-rated show on television for five consecutive seasons in the 1980s, centered on the Huxtable family, an upper-middle-class African American family living in Brooklyn. It featured a renowned comedian as the patriarch, Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable, and his lawyer wife, Clair. The show broke ground by portraying a positive and successful Black family, challenging stereotypes and inspiring a generation. Which show, known for its heartwarming humor and family values, is this?

This scientist, who initially had no formal academic training, was encouraged by anthropologist Louis Leakey to study chimpanzees in their natural habitat. In 1960, she began her groundbreaking research at Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania. Her observations challenged prevailing assumptions about chimpanzees, revealing their tool-making abilities, complex social structures, and emotional depth. Who was this primatologist whose work revolutionized our understanding of animal behavior and conservation?

This president holds the unique distinction of being the only person to lead both the executive and judicial branches of the U.S. government. Appointed Secretary of War by President Theodore Roosevelt, he later succeeded him as President in 1909. After his presidency, he fulfilled a lifelong dream by becoming Chief Justice of the Supreme Court in 1921. Which president, known for his jovial personality and considerable size, was once famously rumored to have gotten stuck in the White House bathtub?

This team, founded in 1960, was initially a member of the American Football League (AFL) before joining the NFL following the merger in 1970. They played their home games at the iconic Mile High Stadium until 2000, before moving to Empower Field at Mile High. They have won eight AFC Championships and three Super Bowl titles, with their most recent victory in Super Bowl 50 in 2016. What is the name of this NFL team, known for its orange and blue uniforms and passionate fanbase?

This ocean is the third-largest on Earth. It's home to a variety of unique marine life, including the endangered dugong and the elusive whale shark. It's also the site of the Maldives, a chain of 26 atolls known for their luxurious resorts and pristine beaches. This ocean is named after the the subcontinent which forms its northern rim. Which ocean is this, a major trade route for centuries, connecting East Africa, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia?

This theologian's translation of the Bible into vernacular German made it accessible to a wider audience and contributed to the spread of literacy. He was a key figure in the Protestant Reformation, which led to the establishment of new Christian denominations. His 95 Theses, nailed to a church door in Wittenberg in 1517, challenged the Catholic Church's practice of selling indulgences. Who was this German reformer, whose teachings emphasized the importance of faith alone for salvation?

This sporting event was won by Tadej Pogacar from Slovenia on team UAE in 2024. This iconic race, first held in 1903, was initially conceived as a publicity stunt to boost newspaper sales. Its grueling cycling route covers over 3,000 kilometers across France, incorporating various terrains like mountains, flatlands, and cobbled roads. The leader of the race wears a distinctive yellow jersey, symbolizing the overall standings. Which race, often referred to as the "Grand Boucle," is considered the most prestigious in professional cycling?

This author's early life in a small Colombian town, surrounded by his grandparents' stories and local folklore, heavily influenced his distinctive literary style. He began his career as a journalist, but his passion for storytelling led him to write fiction infused with magical realism. His most celebrated novel, published in 1967, tells the multi-generational saga of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo. This novel became a landmark in Latin American literature and a global bestseller. Who was this Nobel laureate in Literature, often referred to as "Gabo," whose works continue to captivate readers with their blend of fantasy and reality?

Landslides killed at least 257 people in this nation in July 2024. This country is the most populous landlocked nation on Earth and the second most populous country in Africa. This East African nation was once ruled by a female pharaoh, Candace of Meroë, around the 1st century AD. It's the only country in Africa never to have been colonized by European powers, except for a brief occupation by Italy from 1936 to 1941.  What nation is home to the ancient rock-hewn churches of Lalibela with the capital of Addis Ababa?

This element is the most abundant element in the universe, constituting roughly 75% of all normal matter. It's a key component of stars, where it fuels nuclear fusion reactions. On Earth, it exists primarily in compounds like water and hydrocarbons. Despite its abundance, it's rarely found in its pure form and requires energy to isolate. What element, with just one proton and one electron, is the lightest and simplest in the periodic table?

This jazz singer, whose birth name was Eleanora Fagan, was nicknamed "Lady Day" by her friend and musical partner, saxophonist Lester Young. Her signature song, "Strange Fruit," a haunting protest against lynching, became a controversial yet defining moment in her career. Despite a troubled personal life marked by substance abuse and legal battles, her raw, emotional vocal style and innovative phrasing left an enduring mark on jazz music. Who was this iconic artist, often regarded as one of the greatest jazz vocalists of all time?

This 13th-century philosopher and theologian, known as the "Angelic Doctor," was a key figure in the Scholasticism movement. He is best known for his magnum opus, the "Summa Theologica," a comprehensive systematic exposition of Christian theology. His teachings, which combined Aristotelian philosophy with Christian doctrine, remain influential in Catholic theology today. Who was this Dominican friar, declared a Doctor of the Church in 1567?

This team, founded in 1993 as an expansion team, plays its home games at Coors Field, known for its high altitude and hitter-friendly environment. They hold the MLB record for the most batting titles won by a team since their inception. Their most successful season came in 2007, when they won the National League pennant and reached the World Series. Which team, named after the iconic mountain range that dominates their home state, is this?

This ocean is home to the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, the longest mountain range on Earth, spanning over 10,000 miles. This ocean played a crucial role in the Age of Exploration, as European powers sought new trade routes to Asia and the Americas. It's also the site of the Bermuda Triangle, a region known for mysterious disappearances of ships and aircraft. This ocean, the second-largest in the world, was named after the Greek titan Atlas. What ocean, separating the Americas from Europe and Africa, is this?

This aviation pioneer, born in Atchison, Kansas, in 1897, was a vocal advocate for women's rights and a role model for aspiring female aviators. During her attempt to circumnavigate the globe in 1937, she mysteriously disappeared over the Pacific Ocean, sparking numerous theories and searches that continue to this day. She was  the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean in 1932. Who was this iconic figure, whose legacy lives on as a symbol of courage and adventure?

This author's father was a renowned physician and public health advocate in France. He was known for his close friendships with the composer Reynaldo Hahn and painter Lucien Daudet. He served a year of military service, stationed at Coligny Barracks in Orléans, an experience that would later feature in his novel. He gained literary recognition in the early 20th century for his monumental novel, a seven-volume exploration of memory, time, and society, often considered one of the greatest works of literature ever written. Who is this author of "In Search of Lost Time"?

This animal's stripes, unique to each individual, were once thought to serve as camouflage. However, recent research suggests the stripes may disrupt the visual perception of biting flies, thus deterring them from landing. Their social structure revolves around small family groups led by a dominant stallion. They are primarily herbivorous grazers, feeding on grasses and leaves in the African savannas. What equid, closely related to horses and donkeys, is known for its distinctive black and white striped coat?

This president's early life was marked by tragedy, losing both parents before the age of ten. He later became a successful mining engineer, working internationally and amassing considerable wealth. During World War I, he gained recognition for his humanitarian efforts, coordinating food relief for war-torn Europe. Which president, often associated with the Great Depression, saw his popularity plummet due to his administration's perceived inability to address the economic crisis?

This organization has been engaged in fighting along the northern border of Israel. The group, whose name translates to "Party of God," was founded in 1982 in response to the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. It receives financial and military support from Iran and is considered a terrorist organization by many Western nations. They have been a significant political force in Lebanon, holding seats in parliament and participating in the government. Which group, known for its military wing and social services network, is this?

This iconic artwork, consisting of 32 canvases was first exhibited in Los Angeles in 1962. It was initially met with mixed reactions, with some critics questioning its artistic merit. Despite the controversy, the work, which depcits pantry staples, quickly gained recognition as a defining piece of Pop Art, a movement that challenged traditional notions of what constituted art. The artist, Andy Warhol, is known for his use of mass-produced imagery and his exploration of consumer culture. What is the name of this artwork, now considered a masterpiece of modern art?

This monarch's reign of 72 years and 110 days is the longest recorded of any monarch of a sovereign country in European history. He ascended the throne at the age of four, following the death of his father. He built the magnificent Palace of Versailles, which served as the seat of the French government and a symbol of his absolute power. He was known as the "Sun King," and he adopted the sun as his emblem. Who was this absolute monarch, who famously declared, "L'État, c'est moi" ("I am the state")?

This Great Lake, the only one entirely within the United States, is named after the Ojibwe word "mishigami," meaning "large lake." Its shoreline stretches over 1,600 miles and includes the Indiana Dunes National Park. It serves as a vital shipping route, connecting the Midwest to the Atlantic Ocean via the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway. What is the name of this freshwater lake, the second-largest of the Great Lakes by volume, which has a port in Chicago?

This band's debut album, "Appetite for Destruction," released in 1987, is one of the best-selling albums of all time. Their hit song, "Sweet Child o' Mine," features a guitar solo by Slash widely considered one of the greatest in rock history. Their infamous feud with Nirvana at the 1992 MTV Video Music Awards is a legendary moment in rock 'n' roll history. Known for their rebellious image and energetic live shows, they were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012. Which band, fronted by Axl Rose, is this?

This footballer, born Edson Arantes do Nascimento, earned his nickname as a child while playing for a local youth team. He won three FIFA World Cups with Brazil, the only player to achieve this feat. He scored a record 1,281 goals in his career, earning him the title "The King of Football." Which football legend, who started his professional career at the age of 15 with Santos FC, is this?

This miniseries, based on the non-fiction book by Stephen Ambrose, depicts the experiences of Easy Company, 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division, from their training in Georgia to the end of World War II. The series, which aired in 2001, was executive produced by Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks, and features an ensemble cast, including Damian Lewis, Ron Livingston, and Donnie Wahlberg. Which miniseries, known for its realistic portrayal of combat and the bonds formed among soldiers, is this?

This city, situated on the Yangtze River Delta, is the most populous city proper in the world. Its name translates to "Upon the Sea," reflecting its location on the East China Sea. It's a major global financial center, home to the an important stock exchange and the Lujiazui financial district. It's also known for its iconic skyline, featuring the Oriental Pearl Tower and a namesake World Financial Center. What city, often referred to as the "Paris of the East," is this?

This scientist was a member of Parliament for the University of Cambridge for a brief period in the late 17th century. He suffered a nervous breakdown in 1693, possibly due to mercury poisoning from his alchemical experiments. He developed calculus, a branch of mathematics essential for modern physics and engineering. This scientist is most renowned for formulating the laws of motion and universal gravitation, laying the groundwork for classical mechanics. Who was this brilliant mind, often regarded as the father of modern science?

This quarterback, nicknamed "Joe Cool" for his calm demeanor under pressure, led his team to four Super Bowl victories in the 1980s. He's known for orchestrating "The Catch," a game-winning touchdown pass in the 1982 NFC Championship Game. He played college football for Notre Dame, where he led the Fighting Irish to a national championship in 1977. He was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2000. Who was this quarterback, considered one of the greatest of all time, who played most of his career with the San Francisco 49ers?

This river played host to the 2024 Olympic opening ceremonies as athletes paraded on boats. The Olympic host nation, France, spent $1.5 billion dollars to clean up this river which has long held unsafe levels of sewage for swimming. This river's name derives from the Celtic word "Sequana," referring to the goddess of the river. Its meandering path through northern France spans 777 kilometers, flowing through the heart of Paris and under its iconic bridges. Name this river whose banks in Paris are known as the "Rive Gauche" and "Rive Droite."

This novel, initially published under the pseudonym Ellis Bell, was met with mixed reviews upon its release in 1847. Set in the harsh and windswept Yorkshire moors, the story revolves around the tumultuous relationship between Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw, whose passionate love is marred by revenge, class divisions, and a haunting atmosphere. The novel's complex narrative structure, shifting between multiple narrators and timelines, adds to its enigmatic appeal. What is the title of this Gothic masterpiece by Emiliy Bronte, often considered one of the greatest works of English literature?

This conflict, documented by the contemporary historian Thucydides, was a clash between two powerful alliances led by Athens and Sparta. It lasted for nearly three decades, from 431 to 404 BC, and resulted in the decline of the Athenian Golden Age. The war's origins were rooted in the growing tensions between the Athenian-led Delian League and the Spartan-led Peloponnesian League. What was the name of this ancient Greek war, known for its devastating impact on the region?

This author's father was a prominent theologian and her sister was a pioneer in women's education. Although she had limited firsthand experience with slavery, her most famous work, published in 1852, had a profound impact on the abolitionist movement. This book was so influential that it is often cited as one of the causes of the American Civil War. Who was this author, whose fictional portrayal of the horrors of slavery in "Uncle Tom's Cabin" sparked outrage and fueled the national debate on the issue?

This European capital, located on the Manzanares River, is known for its high altitude, making it one of the highest capital cities in Europe. Its central square, the Puerta del Sol, is the symbolic center of Spain and the country's road network. The city is home to the "Golden Triangle of Art," consisting of three world-renowned museums: the Prado, Reina Sofía, and Thyssen-Bornemisza. Which city, the capital of Spain, is this?

This footballer, born in a shantytown on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, began his professional career at the age of 15. He played for several clubs throughout his career, including Barcelona, Napoli, and Boca Juniors, achieving legendary status in Naples. He led Argentina to victory in the 1986 World Cup, scoring the infamous "Hand of God" goal and the "Goal of the Century" in the same match against England. Who was this controversial figure, known for his exceptional dribbling skills and passionate personality, whose life was marked by both triumph and tragedy?

This cybersecurity firm's faulty update in July 2024 triggered a widespread system failure, impacting millions of Windows devices worldwide. The outage led to disruptions in various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and emergency services. Although not a cyberattack, this incident raised concerns about the vulnerability of digital infrastructure to software glitches. Which company, known for its endpoint security solutions, was responsible for this major outage?

This scientist, known for his quirky personality and bongo playing, was not only a key figure in the Manhattan Project but also cracked safes for fun at Los Alamos. His namesake diagrams, a simple way to visualize complex particle interactions, revolutionized quantum physics. He received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1965 for his work on quantum electrodynamics. This scientist also gave a famous lecture in 1959 proposing the manipulation of matter at the atomic level, which laid the groundwork for nanotechnology. Who is this influential figure, often referred to as "The Great Explainer"?

This philosopher's teachings, which emphasized personal and governmental morality, correct social relationships, justice, and sincerity, have deeply influenced Chinese and East Asian thought and life for over two millennia. He believed in the importance of strong family bonds, ancestor veneration, and respect for elders. His followers recorded his teachings in the Analects, a collection of sayings and ideas that has become a fundamental text in Chinese philosophy. Which philosopher, born in 551 BCE in the state of Lu, is this?

This author, known for his minimalist writing style, worked as an ambulance driver in Italy during World War I. He was part of the "Lost Generation" of American expatriates in Paris during the 1920s, where he befriended other literary figures like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Gertrude Stein. A keen sportsman, he enjoyed bullfighting, hunting, and fishing, which often featured in his works. Who was this Nobel laureate in Literature, famous for novels like "The Sun Also Rises" and "For Whom the Bell Tolls"?

This sitcom, set in Pasadena, California, follows the lives of four socially awkward scientists and their interactions with their aspiring actress neighbor. The show's theme song, performed by the Barenaked Ladies, offers a brief summary of the universe's history from the Big Bang to the present day. The show launched the careers of several actors, including Jim Parsons, who won four Emmy Awards for his portrayal of the brilliant but socially inept Sheldon Cooper. What is the name of this long-running sitcom, known for its quirky humor and scientific references?

This president was born in Kinderhook, New York, in 1782, making him the first U.S. president to be born a U.S. citizen, rather than a British subject. He was also the first president whose native language was not English; he grew up speaking Dutch. Nicknamed "The Little Magician" for his political skills, he served as Secretary of State under Andrew Jackson before becoming vice president and eventually president in 1837. Which president faced the Panic of 1837, a major economic downturn shortly after taking office?

A speech by this man reflects that, if an assassination against him had succeeded, he would have been unable support the Southern Christian Leadership Conference during the Birmingham Campaign. This man gave the "I've Been to the Mountaintop" speech, in Memphis in 1968, the night before he was successfully assassinated by James Earl Ray. Name this civil rights leader who also gave the "I Have a Dream" speech.

In this city, fifteen "moonlight towers" built in the nineteenth century still operate at night. This seat of Travis County has suburbs named San Marcos and Round Rock, and hosts the South by Southwest festival. This city's namesake was defeated in an 1836 presidential election by Sam Houston. Name this city that trails San Antonio and Dallas in population, the capital of Texas.

A ghostly Red Skull presides over one of these items, which must be obtained by sacrifice on Vomir. The Eye of Agamotto houses a green one of these items wielded by Stephen Strange. Possessing all 6 of these items allows one character to destroy half of all life with the snap of his fingers. Thanos sought to control aspects of the universe like space, time, and reality with what colorful gems from the Marvel Cinematic Universe?

Larvae of the insect family Agro-myzi-dae are "miners" of these structures, where bundle-sheath cells are found. These structures can be "palmately compound," and they have parallel veins in monocots. Carotenoid pigments that are yellow and orange become more prominent in these structures before they are shed by deciduous trees. Name these green plant structures that are the primary site of photosynthesis.

Each of the two Jelling stones was raised by a king of these people, Gorm the Old and Harald Bluetooth. These people attacked monasteries in places like Lindisfarne in 793, and they encountered "skraelings" in Vinland during the expedition of Leif Eriksson. The "Great Heathen Army" was made up of what seagoing Germanic people who often decorated their ships with dragon heads, but did not actually wear horned helmets?

This gymnast began practicing at just two years old, inspired by watching the "Magnificent Seven" win gold at the 1996 Olympics. She captained both the 2012 "Fierce Five" and 2016 "Final Five" U.S. women's Olympic gymnastics teams to gold medals. She also won individual golds in floor exercise and on the balance beam. Known for her powerful tumbling and expressive floor routines, she became a vocal advocate for survivors of sexual abuse after publicly sharing her own experiences. Who is this decorated gymnast?

A character in this novel protects his sister, Georgiana, and plans to marry Catherine de Bourgh's daughter. In this novel, playboy George Wickham and nobleman Charles Bingley romantically pursue Lydia and Jane, two of the protagonist's four sisters. "A truth universally acknowledged" about marriage among the wealthy begins what Jane Austen novel in which Elizabeth Bennet at first dislikes, but eventually marries, Mr. Darcy?

Kimberly Cheatle, the director of this US federal agency, resigned on July 23, 2024. She resigned due to heavy criticism in her agency's failures in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump. Originally founded in 1865 to combat the spread of counterfeit currency, this federal law enforcement agency's mandate expanded in 1901 to include the protection of the President of the United States. It investigates financial crimes such as counterfeiting, fraud, and identity theft. It also protects not only the President and Vice President but also their families, former presidents, and major presidential and vice presidential candidates. What is the name of this agency under the Department of Homeland Security?

Zoologist Sten Bergman suggested that a very large species of this animal once lived on the Kamchatka Peninsula. Climate change has caused members of a northern species of this animal to drown while swimming between ice floes, and thousands of its Kodiak subspecies are attracted to annual salmon runs. Name this omnivorous mammal with "grizzly" and "polar" species.

Securities backed by these products are created and sold by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which were taken over by the federal government in 2008. In 2007, during the Great Recession, the "adjustable rate" type of this financial product rose too quickly for their borrowers to pay them off, leading to massive foreclosures. Give this term for a loan taken out for the purchase of a house.

This man's successful guerilla campaign in the Sierra Maestra began with only nineteen people. This man's "History Will Absolve Me" speech became the manifesto of the Twenty-sixth of July Movement. Due to health issues, this man handed the presidency over to his brother, Raul, in 2008. Fulgencio Batista's government was overthrown by what revolutionary who established the Communist party in Cuba?

This man claimed victory in his nation's presidential election on July 28, 2024, but the results have been contested by many international organizations. This many was running for re-election against Edmundo González Urrutia representing the Unitary Platform. Prior to serving as president he was appointed to a number of positions under President Hugo Chávez. Name this leader of Venezuela who has been accused of running sham elections and being an autocrat.

This singer asks "think of me fondly when your hands are on her" in a song that may have been inspired by Joshua Bassett. Since it took inspiration from "Misery Business," this singer of "happier" added a Hayley Williams writing credit to a song that criticizes an ex's behavior as being "like a damn sociopath." Name this former Disney Channel actress whose explosive 2021 album, SOUR, includes the songs "deja vu,""good 4 u," and "drivers license."

A New York Times article about this war outlined Daniel Ellsberg's leak of documents that described the rise of Ngo Dinh Diem [no din dee-yem] and the goal of containing Chinese influence, nicknamed the Pentagon Papers. For negotiating this war's ceasefire, Henry Kissinger controversially earned a Nobel Peace Prize. Saigon was renamed Ho Chi Minh City after what war in which an American-backed force was defeated by communists in Southeast Asia?

Until 1793, statues of twenty-eight kings of Judah stood along this building's west side. Eugene Viollet-le-Duc restored this building in the 1800s, and added a spire that was destroyed in a 2019 fire. This building is known for its flying buttresses and enormous rose windows, and dominates the ˆIle de la Cite, an island in the River Seine. Name this Catholic cathedral which experienced a fire in 2019 and whose name means "Our Lady of Paris."

This team's original name was inspired by the prospectors who flocked to California during the 1849 Gold Rush. Their iconic logo features a stylized red and gold "SF" oval. The team has won five Super Bowl championships, with their last victory in 1995 under the leadership of quarterback Steve Young and wide receiver Jerry Rice. They play their home games at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California. What is this NFL franchise known for its rich history and passionate fan base?

In one song, this artist declares "your memory is ecstasy" and claims to "miss you more than life". This singer of "Ghost" begins another song with The Kid LAROI saying "I do the same thing, I told you that I never would" in "STAY". This singer of "Love Yourself" is featured in a remix of Luis Fonsi's "Despacito". Name this Canadian singer who became a superstar at fifteen with the release of "Baby".

Brumbies are a feral type of these animals that roam Australia. Although the Hall of the Bulls is the most famous section of the Lascaux caves, these animals are the most common to be painted on its walls. The rise of the Proto-Indo-Europeans is tied to their domestication of these animals on the Russian steppe. Parthian archers mastered the ability to turn around and shoot arrows while riding what animals that can be used to pull chariots and plows?

A planned highway across this region called BR-230 is largely unpaved between Altamira and Benjamin Constant. Most of the state of Mato Grosso is south of this region; Mato Grosso also includes some of the Pantanal wetlands. Contrary to popular belief, the red-eyed tree frog is not native to this region, but piranhas and anacondas are. Dust from the Sahara Desert blows across the Atlantic Ocean to fertilize what massive tropical ecosystem around the longest river in South America?

During a victory boat parade, Cam Brate caught the Super Bowl trophy that this player tossed to him. At his current team, this player, who briefly retired in February of 2021, reunited with longtime teammate Rob Gronkowski. This player won his 7th Super Bowl ring after defeating the Kansas City Chiefs in 2021, making him the player with the most in NFL history. What long time Patriots quarterback ended his career with the Buccaneers?

This city was recently announced as the host of the 2034 Winter Olympics. This city's unique street numbering system, based on its location relative to the city's temple, divides the city into quadrants and uses a grid system based on 100 blocks per mile. It hosted the 2002 Winter Olympics, which were marked by controversy surrounding judging in figure skating. It is home to the largest saltwater lake in the Western Hemisphere, which has a salinity level three to five times greater than that of the ocean. What is the name of this city, nicknamed the "Crossroads of the West"?

This empire conducted restoration projects on the Dome of the Rock and the walls of Jerusalem in the nineteenth century. Near the end of this empire, it was nicknamed a "sick man." A sixteenth-century ruler of this empire known as "the Lawgiver" was its longest-reigning sultan. Suleiman the Magnificent ruled what empire that fell in the twentieth century and was based in what is now Turkey?

This university is home to the Whiffenpoofs, the oldest collegiate a cappella group in the US. Walter Camp, a rugby player for this university, created American football. Former president William Howard Taft and both presidents Bush were members of a secret society at this school that meets in "The Tomb," the Skull and Bones Society. This university is located near Long Island Sound in New Haven, Connecticut. Name this Ivy League university that rivals Harvard.

This artist painted Olive Trees in a Mountainous Landscape while staying in the village of Saint-Remy in an asylum. This artist left the Yellow House in Arles after having a falling out with his friend Paul Gauguin, and painted a series of Sunflowers after moving to France from the Netherlands. Name this artist who painted a looming cypress tree under a swirling sky in his Starry Night.

This woman successfully sued William Randolph Hearst for libel after one of his newspapers falsely claimed that she had been stealing to support a cocaine habit. This woman, who married Frank Butler after besting him in a contest, was named Watanya Cicilla by Sitting Bull, who performed with her for a few months in 1885. "Little Sure Shot" was the touring nickname of what prolific sharpshooter who performed in Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show?

In this novel, Constance Bonacieux tries to retrieve a pair of diamond studs that Queen Anne had given to the Duke of Buckingham, and a fleur-de-lis tattoo reveals that Milady de Winter is a convict. Cardinal Richelieu's plan is foiled in this novel by d'Artagnan and a small group of swordsmen. Name this novel by Alexandre Dumas in which Athos, Porthos, and Aramis make the pledge "one for all and all for one."
incorrect2: The Man in the Iron Mask

question: Two songs by this performer say "your silence is my favorite sound" and asks "to give your lack of interest an explanation." With her brother, Finneas, this singer wrote "You Should See Me in a Crown," "Wish You Were Gay," and a song in which this woman sings "I don't want press to put your name next to mine / we're on different lines." Name this singer who performed "Therefore I Am" on the album Happier Than Ever.

This team forfeited the second game of a doubleheader after rock DJ Steve Dahl's "Disco Demolition Night" turned into a riot at Comiskey Park. Kenesaw Mountain Landis banned eight members of this team, including "Shoeless" Joe Jackson, for life after they were accused of intentionally losing the World Series. Lucas Giolito, Eloy Jimenez, and MVP Jose Abreu have been players for what American League baseball team that has a local rivalry with the Chicago Cubs?

On August 1, 2024 this nation played host to the largest prisoner exchange since the end of the Cold War. The exchange was between Russia and western nations including Germany, Poland, and the United States, and it included Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter for the Wall Street Journal. The exchange occurred at Ankara Esenboğa Airport in this nation that is led by prime minister Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. This country's national flag, featuring a white crescent moon and star on a red background, is believed to be inspired by a dream of the first Ottoman Sultan, Osman I. Name this nation which is separated by the Bosphorus Strait.

This country's Project 596 was part of its "Two Bombs, One Satellite" goal. This country broke with the Soviet Union over ideological differences in the application of Leninism. In 1972, this country hosted Richard Nixon for a diplomatic visit organized by Zhou Enlai. Name this communist power that, for much of the twentieth century, was led by Chairman Mao Zedong.

This city's Adams Morgan neighborhood was partially shaped by the L'Enfant and McMillan Plans. This city and its suburbs are surrounded by the Beltway, and it is across the Potomac River from Arlington, Virginia. A Daniel Chester French sculpture in this city sits across a reflecting pool from an obelisk on the National Mall. Name this planned city, the location of the Lincoln Memorial, Capitol Hill, and the White House.

This substance makes up the mantle of the moon Triton, and erupts from "tiger stripes" on Enceladus to form the E ring of Saturn. It is not gas, but this substance names a type of giant planet exemplified by Uranus. Oort cloud objects, including comets, consist mainly of this substance, which forms a crust over Europa's possibly-liquid oceans. Name this substance abundant at Earth's polar caps, the frozen form of water.

Systems composed of a pendulum and this device can be modeled by the Duffing equation. This device's force is equal to stiffness times extension, or "kx", according to Hooke's law, which describes these simple harmonic oscillators. Name this device, used in trampolines and pogo sticks, that stores energy in its often-metal coils.

In this colony, John Peter Zenger was acquitted of libeling governor William Cosby, which helped establish freedom of the press. The Stamp Act Congress was held in this colony's Federal Hall. John Burgoyne failed to establish control of this colony's Hudson River Valley, and was defeated in this colony at the Battle of Saratoga. Name this home colony of Alexander Hamilton, where the British failed to capture the city of Albany.

This actress began her career on the Australian stage, earning accolades for her performances in "Oleanna" and "Hamlet." Her breakthrough role as Queen Elizabeth I in the 1998 film "Elizabeth" garnered her a Golden Globe and an Oscar nomination. She has since starred in a diverse range of films, from blockbusters like "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy to critically acclaimed dramas like "Blue Jasmine," for which she won an Academy Award.  Who is this versatile performer, who starred alongside Brad Pitt in "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button"?

This soccer player scored a memorable "Olimpico" goal directly from a corner kick against Canada in the 2012 London Olympics. Known for her powerful left foot and signature goal celebration, she has won two FIFA Women's World Cup titles and an Olympic gold medal with the U.S. Women's National Team. Her distinctive purple hair became synonymous with her outspoken personality and activism for LGBTQ+ rights and gender equality. Who is this celebrated winger who announced her retirement from professional soccer in 2023?

This country's city of Maidan Shahr was briefly led by Zarifa Ghafari, its youngest female mayor. A bombing killed nearly two hundred people at this country's Hamid Karzai Airport. This country's last president, Ashraf Ghani, fled to nearby Uzbekistan in August 2021. Two weeks of airlift evacuations followed the American withdrawal from what Asian country led from Kabul by the Taliban?

A namesake species of pink rattlesnake is endemic to this natural feature. Supai Village, the capital of the Hava-supai Indian Reservation, is located within this feature, which is the gateway to the afterlife in Hopi religion. The Kaibab Plateau is bisected by this natural feature, which became a national park after John Wesley Powell mapped it in what is now Arizona. The Colorado River carved out what absurdly large gorge in the American southwest?

In this novel, Matthewson makes a wager at the Eldorado Saloon that this novel's protagonist cannot move a one-thousand-pound load, and loses his money to Hans and Pete. This novel's protagonist kills a group of Yeehat Native Americans to avenge the death of John Thornton, the first man to treat him well since he was trained by a man in a red sweater to be a sled dog. Name this Jack London novel in which Buck answers the title summons by joining a wolf pack.

Gaemi, this type natural disaster, struck Taiwan in late July 2024 which led to the evacuation of over 8000 people. The deadliest on record, Nina in 1975, caused over 200,000 deaths in China due to catastrophic flooding. These powerful storms typically occur between May and November, with peak activity in August and September. They can cause significant damage through strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges. What are these tropical cyclones called, which form over warm ocean waters in the Northwest Pacific Ocean?

This thinker wrote a popular newspaper column under the pseudonym Silence Do-good, and used another false name when he published Poor Richard's Almanac. This politician created America's first volunteer fire department, and served as the first Postmaster General in the presidential cabinet. Name this founding father whose portrait appears on the one-hundred dollar bill.

A character with super strength in this film sings about "Pressure, like a drip, drip, drip that'll never stop." In this film, characters sing about ill prophecies made by a character who "We Don't Talk About." In this film, the power-less Mirabel sings about the "gifts" given to her family by a "miracle" in the form of a candle. Name this Disney musical film about the magical Madrigal family.

In the beliefs of the Latter Day Saints movement, this man was the mortal form of the angel Michael, and lived near Jackson County, Missouri. In Islam, Iblis was banished from Heaven for refusing to bow before this man. This man became the father of Seth after his eldest son committed the first murder. Cain and Abel were the sons of what husband of Lilith and Eve, the first man created by God?

This is the only player in Davidson College's history to have a jersey number retired. This player, who in 2022 broke a record held by Ray Allen, recently won his fourth NBA championship and first finals MVP after defeating the Boston Celtics. This player is a member of the "Splash Brothers" with Klay Thompson. Name this point guard for the Golden State Warriors.

This Supreme Court Chief Justice, a practicing Roman Catholic, is known for his conservative leanings but has also authored some surprising liberal decisions. He served as a law clerk for Justice William Rehnquist and later worked in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations. Appointed Chief Justice in 2005 by George W. Bush, he has presided over several landmark cases, including the Affordable Care Act and same-sex marriage decisions. Who is this current Chief Justice of the United States?

One of these places in Utah has multiple spires of rock called hoodoos. Climbers visit monoliths like Half Dome and El Capitan in another one of these places. A tri-state one of these places is home to multiple geysers including Old Faithful. Some of these places in California include Joshua Tree and Yosemite. Name these protected areas in the United States, the oldest one of which is Yellowstone.

Oxfam was founded to alleviate a famine in this country. This country celebrates "No Day," a holiday that commemorates a refusal to cooperate with Benito Mussolini, given by Prime Minister Ioannis Metaxas. The Earl of Elgin looted marble sculptures from this country, and the British Museum refuses to repatriate them. Since 2007, a debt crisis has plagued what country where the Parthenon stands in Athens?

Heron's formula calculates the area of this type of shape. The orthocenter is found at the intersection of the altitudes of this shape. If the side lengths of this shape are all different, this shape is "scalene," and if two of its sides are equal, it is called "isosceles." If this shape has a ninety-degree angle, the relative size of its sides is described by the Pythagorean Theorem. Name this polygon with three sides.

An unfinished work by this composer includes a "Lacrimosa" section that was completed by Franz Sussmayr after this man died at age thirty-five. This composer wrote an unfinished Requiem and forty-one symphonies, the last of which is nicknamed "Jupiter." Name this prolific Austrian child prodigy who wrote the chamber piece Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, which is sometimes nicknamed "A Little Night Music."

The Lockheed WP-3D Orion is a nicknamed a "hunter" of these systems, which cannot form near the equator due to a weak Coriolis force. The Saffir-Simpson scale classifies these weather systems, which have an eyewall that drives a storm surge onto land in instances of these system classified as "Category 5." Name these violent, tropical Atlantic cyclones exemplified by Ida and Katrina.

This historian wrote the book The Naval War of 1812 to advocate for building American naval power, which he later accomplished as a politician by funding the Great White Fleet. With the First Volunteer Cavalry Regiment, this man became the "Hero of San Juan Hill" before being elected Vice President under McKinley. Name this member of the Rough Riders, who was the twenty-sixth U.S. president.

This team, initially a member of the American Football League, played its first season in Los Angeles in 1960 before relocating to San Diego in 1961. Led by quarterback Dan Fouts and wide receiver Charlie Joiner, their "Air Coryell" offense was a dominant force in the 1970s and early 1980s. They returned to Los Angeles in 2017 and currently share SoFi Stadium with the Los Angeles Rams. What is the name of this NFL team whose colors are powder blue and sunshine gold?

This iconic British rock band initially formed under a different name in 1968, inspired by a comment about their potential career trajectory. Their debut album featured songs like "Good Times Bad Times" and "Dazed and Confused," showcasing their blues-rock roots.  They quickly gained a reputation for their powerful live performances and influential albums which contained the iconic anthem "Stairway to Heaven." The band's music, while commercially successful, was often met with critical disdain, particularly for their perceived appropriation of blues and folk traditions. Which band, known for their mix of heavy rock, blues, and folk influences, achieved legendary status despite their early negative reception?

This city's Muddy River runs through Olmsted Park, a part of this city's Emerald Necklace. This city's Back Bay area is on the Charles River, across from its sister city, Cambridge. This city's MLB team plays near Kenmore Square in a park that holds the Green Monster, and one end of Beacon Hill forms this city's namesake Common. Fenway Park hosts the Red Sox in what capital city of Massachusetts?

This island, which is part of France's only overseas territory, is hosting the surfing competition for the 2024 Paris Olympics. The overwater bungalow, a luxurious accommodation option popular with honeymooners, was first invented here. The French Polynesian island, shaped like a figure-eight, is the largest in the Society Islands archipelago. It is renowned for its black sand beaches, lush rainforests, and stunning volcanic peaks.  What is this island, often associated with the painter Paul Gauguin, who captured its beauty in his vibrant artworks?

This country was forbidden from allying with Spain in the Peace of Utrecht. Nobles of this country attempted to dethrone a boy king in a rebellion called the Fronde. This officially Catholic country persecuted the Huguenots after the Edict of Fontainebleau. The palace of Versailles was once a royal residence in what country led by the "Sun King," Louis XIV?

Maurice Wilson planned to crash a plane on top of this mountain, where he died by other means. George Mallory may have summitted this mountain before disappearing on it, and legendarily declared that he would climb it "because it's there." Tenzing Norgay coordinated the first successful climb of this mountain in 1953 with Edmund Hillary. Name this twenty-nine-thousand-foot-high peak in the Himalayan Mountains, the highest mountain on Earth.

Thomas Edison built the first American power plant, the Pearl Street Station, to light street lamps in this place. In 1920, Italian anarchists set off a bomb in this place that killed forty people; the bomb was carried in a wagon that stopped in front of the headquarters of J.P. Morgan. The eight blocks of this place stretch from the East River to Broadway and include the NYSE building. Name this street in downtown Manhattan, the heart of New York's Financial District.

This country's secret police, SAVAK, was blamed for the Cinema Rex fire, which killed hundreds of people in 1979. A year earlier, dozens of people were killed in this country's Jaleh Square on "Black Friday"by the forces of Reza Pahlavi, who was forced into exile after the rise of Ayatollah Khomeini in an Islamic Revolution. A leader called a "Shah" once led what Asian country where over fifty Americans were taken hostage for four hundred forty-four days in Tehran?

This artist claims "I'll sink my teeth in disbelief 'cause you're the one that I want" in "Love Again." In another song, this artist repeatedly says "if you don't wanna see me dancing with somebody." The line "if you wanna run away with me, I know a galaxy And I can take you for a ride" begins a song that appears on this artist's album Future Nostalgia. Name this Albanian-English singer of "Don't Start Now" and "Levitating."

This literary character usurps the throne of King Pastoria, and is succeeded by Pastoria's daughter after she escapes from the witch Mombi. This character travels from Omaha in a hot air balloon, and is apprenticed to Glinda to learn real magic, although he uses stage magic tricks to confront the Scarecrow and Dorothy. Name this magician who rules a fantasy land in a novel by L. Frank Baum.
answers: Oscar Zoroaster Phadrig Isaac Norman Henkel Emmannuel Ambroise Diggs

question: This term describes the mass of the hypothetical "dark fluid." The Hammett function of a super-acid has this property. In a galvanic cell, oxidation occurs at the electrode with this property. A spontaneous reaction has this kind of change in Gibbs free energy, and a standard enthalpy change of this type makes a reaction exothermic. Anions possess what kind of charge bestowed by a net gain of electrons?

Initially based in the Midwest and known as the Tri-Cities Blackhawks, this NBA franchise has called three cities home throughout its history. It captured its sole championship in 1958 while playing in St. Louis.  Led by Hall-of-Famers Bob Pettit and Cliff Hagan, the team defeated the Boston Celtics in six games. Which team relocated to Atlanta in 1968 and now boasts a red, black, and yellow color scheme?

A group of these animals testing positive for cocaine off the coast of Rio de Janeiro. These ancient creatures, whose ancestors date back over 400 million years, possess a skeleton made entirely of cartilage, giving them incredible flexibility. They have a unique sixth sense, known as electroreception, which allows them to detect the electrical fields generated by other animals, even in murky waters. Their teeth are constantly being replaced throughout their lives, ensuring they always have a sharp set of chompers. What are these fascinating apex predators that play a vital role in maintaining the balance of marine ecosystems?

In a common undergraduate lab, students synthesize this compound through phosphoric acid-catalyzed esterification. This compound's starting chemical was formerly extracted from willow bark by doctors, and its modern form was patented by Bayer. Acetylsalicylic acid is another name for which NSAID pain reliever which can be prescribed in low doses to reduce the likelihood of blood clots or stroke and can cause more gastrointestinal side effects than ibuprofen?

In a game, this character teams up with an alien wisp called Yacker to stop an evil plot disguised as an amusement park. In a cartoon, this character solves problems on Seaside Island with his namesake "Team,"including Miles Prower. This character's first live-action film was significantly delayed due to backlash over his design, and features Ben Schwartz as this character. Name this speedy video game protagonist who works with Tails to save the world from Doctor Eggman.

The last remaining structure of this city's 1915 World's Fair is the Palace of Fine Arts. This city's"painted ladies" are Victorian houses painted in modern colors. The northern tip of this city is home to Ghirardelli Square and Fisherman's Wharf. The Haight-Ashbury neighborhood in this city was the birthplace of the "Summer of Love." The largest Chinatown outside of Asia is in what California city that is home to the Golden Gate Bridge?

This nation-state's leader traditionally threw a ring from the ship Bucentaur into the Adriatic to perform the annual Marriage of the Sea. This republic was led by a Doge, and its namesake capital city contains the Rialto Bridge and Saint Mark's Basilica. Gondolas are flat-bottomed boats that help people move around what Most Serene Republic in modern Italy, whose namesake capital city was built over a complex of canals?

This NFL team, established in 1965, is the only franchise to have played in two different stadiums named after the same soft drink company. They initially played in Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, nicknamed "The Launching Pad," and currently play in Mercedes-Benz Stadium, known for its retractable roof and unique halo scoreboard. Despite reaching the Super Bowl twice, in 1998 and 2016, they have yet to clinch a championship title. Which team is this, whose colors are red and black?

Three days before this battle, a skirmish at Blackburn's Ford gave Jubal Early's men crucial experience. This battle ended with the "Great Skedaddle," when civilian picnickers fled home in a panic after an expected easy victory finished instead as a loss. Irvin McDowell was routed in this battle, where Thomas Jackson earned the nickname "Stonewall." The Battle of Fort Sumter was three months before what July 21, 1861 battle, the first major battle of the Civil War?

In this novel, John Seward receives letters describing Renfield's madness and begging him to help Arthur Holmwood's sick fiancee. A professor in this novel packs a paste of communion wafers around the door of Lucy Westenra's tomb and in the boxes of earth that the title character transports to England from Transylvania. Abraham Van Helsing, Mina Murray, and Jonathan Harker hunt the title Count in what Bram Stoker novel about an archetypical vampire?

Elon Musk threatened to move companies out of this state because of a recently passed law which bars school districts from requiring parents to be notified of a child's gender identification change. This state is home to Death Valley, the hottest and driest place in North America, and Mount Whitney, the highest point in the contiguous United States. It's the most populous state in the US and boasts the world's largest tree by volume, the General Sherman Tree. What state is this, known for its diverse landscapes and entertainment industry?

According to Herodotus, the first female ruler of this civilization was the semi-mythical empress Nitocris, whom Herodotus associated with Menkaure. This civilization was ruled from Amarna by the husband of Nefertiti. Another female ruler of this civilization, Hat-shep-sut, wore masculine clothing to represent the sun god Ra. Name this ancient African civilization that ruled the area around the Nile river.

In 2013, guard Brandon Jennings insisted that this team would win "in six," even though they were swept in the first round of the playoffs. This team won their first championship in 1971, led by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, and took their second in when Brook Lopez and Khris Middleton did finally beat the Suns in six games. Giannis Antetokounmpo plays for what 2021 NBA Champions from eastern Wisconsin?

A poem of this form warns "die single and thine image dies with thee," and urges "now is the time that face should form another" while addressing a subject known as the Fair Youth. Another of these poems addresses a Dark Lady whose lips are less red than coral and whose "breasts are dun," and begins "My Mistress' Eyes are Nothing Like the Sun." Rhyming couplets typically end what fourteen-line poems frequently written by William Shakespeare?

A "geographic" pattern of patches can appear on this organ due to leukoplakia. This organ's frenulum is tied to another body part in ankylo-glossia, and a protruding one is symptomatic of Down syndrome. It is not a tail, but chameleons possess a prehensile one of these organs that is covered in spiny papillae to assist cats with grooming. Sublingual salivary glands and taste buds are associated with which muscular organ inside the mouth?

This film's opening sequence, which features a solitary miner struggling in silence for several minutes, sets the tone for its bleak and intense exploration of ambition and greed. It's set in the early 20th century during the Southern California oil boom and follows Daniel Plainview, a ruthless oil prospector determined to achieve wealth and power at any cost. The film's iconic scene, where Plainview exclaims, "I drink your milkshake!," has become synonymous with its themes of exploitation and capitalist ruthlessness. Name this 2007 film directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, starring Daniel Day-Lewis in an Oscar-winning performance.

This fitness personality died in July 2024. Known for his energetic personality and flamboyant style, he rose to fame in the 1980s with his "Sweatin' to the Oldies" aerobics videos. He advocated for body positivity and inclusivity, encouraging people of all shapes and sizes to embrace fitness. He also hosted a popular talk show and was a frequent guest on late-night television. Who is this fitness icon, known for his signature short shorts and sparkly tank tops?

This place was the destination of the Peoria Party, who carried flags promoting "[this region] or the grave." This territory was the focus of a "Great Migration" in 1843. Expeditions that began in Independence, Missouri, attempted to reach this territory's Willamette Valley. Name this modern state, the endpoint of a namesake migratory Trail that carried European-Americans to the upper west coast.

Surges from this larger body of water breached the levees of Lake Pontchartrain during a 2005 hurricane. The Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill occurred in this body of water, whose coast is home to popular beaches like Panama City and Destin. Hurricane Katrina gained strength on this gulf before it hit New Orleans. This gulf lies west of the Florida Keys. Name this gulf that shares its name with a country south of the United States.

This element, the most abundant metal in the Earth's crust, is extracted from bauxite ore using a process called the Bayer process. It's lightweight, corrosion-resistant, and a good conductor of electricity, making it ideal for various applications, from airplanes and cars to kitchen foil and beverage cans. Its discovery in 1825 by Hans Christian Ørsted revolutionized industries due to its versatility and abundance. What is this element, represented by the symbol Al on the periodic table?

This fearsome ruler, known as the "Scourge of God," united nomadic tribes and led them on a series of devastating campaigns across Europe in the 5th century. He extracted tributes from the Eastern and Western Roman Empires, and his armies sacked numerous cities, including Rome itself. His sudden death in 453, reportedly from a nosebleed on his wedding night, left a power vacuum that led to the fragmentation of the Hunnic Empire. Who was this legendary warrior?

This British rock band, known for their energetic live performances and pioneering the use of the Marshall stack amplifier, released their groundbreaking rock opera "Tommy" in 1969. Their early hits included songs like "My Generation" and "I Can't Explain." The band's drummer, Keith Moon, was known for his explosive drumming style, but his untimely death in 1978 marked a turning point for the group. This band performed at the Super Bowl in 2010 in Miami. Who is this influential band, whose other members included Roger Daltrey, Pete Townshend, and John Entwistle?

This athlete was the first person to break four world records in the same track event. She broke her own world record in the 400-meter hurdles at the 2024 Summer Olympics, securing her second consecutive gold medal in the event. She's the first woman to break both the 52-second and 51-second barriers in the 400m hurdles. She also contributed to Team USA's victory in the women's 4x400m relay at those same Olympics. Who is this American track star?

This musical artist released his final album titled “Bando Stone & the New World” under his stage name in July 2024. His thought-provoking song "This Is America," released in 2018, sparked widespread conversations about gun violence and racial injustice in the United States. It won four Grammy Awards, including Song of the Year and Record of the Year. The multi-talented artist, known for his roles in the TV shows "Community" and "Atlanta," has also achieved critical acclaim for his music. What is Donald Glover's stage name for his musical career?

Historically, this sea has played a significant role in the development of Mediterranean civilizations, serving as a crucial trade route and a battleground for various empires. The sea, known for its picturesque islands and stunning coastal scenery, is home to over 1,300 islands, most of which are located along the Croatian coast. What is the name of this elongated body of water separating the Italian Peninsula from the Balkan Peninsula?

This author's early life was marked by tragedy, with the deaths of her mother and half-sister leading to her first mental breakdown. She was a key member of the Bloomsbury Group, an influential intellectual and artistic circle in early 20th-century London. Her experimental novels, like "Mrs. Dalloway" and "To the Lighthouse," employ stream-of-consciousness narration and interior monologues. Who was this modernist writer who also penned the feminist essay "A Room of One's Own"?

This president famously declared, "The business of America is business." He ascended to the presidency following the sudden death of Warren G. Harding and won re-election in 1924. He advocated for limited government intervention in the economy and his presidency coincided with a period of economic prosperity known as the "Roaring Twenties." Name this president, known for his taciturn personality, earning him the nickname "Silent Cal."

The remains of a leader of this movement, Martin Bucer, were burned by Mary I. The Marburg Colloquy was called to resolve a dispute between Huldrych Zwingli and another leader of this movement. The Council of Trent codified the "Counter-" response to this movement, whose early proponents criticized the sale of indulgences. This movement started on All Saints' Day, 1517, when Martin Luther posted his 95 Theses in Wittenberg. Name this historical period in which Christian churches broke away from the Roman Catholic Church.

This city recently experienced a tragedy on August 9, 2024, when Voepass Linhas Aéreas Flight 2283 crashed while attempting to land at Guarulhos International Airport, killing all 62 people on board. This incident was the deadliest aviation accident in Brazil since the crash of TAM Airlines Flight 3054 in 2007. This city is the most populous urban area outside of Asia. What is this city, the largest in South America and a major economic and cultural hub of Brazil?

This actor's portrayal of a mentally troubled comedian descending into madness in the 2019 film "Joker" earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor. He is known for his method acting approach and his commitment to animal rights activism. Earlier in his career, he gained recognition for his roles in films like "Gladiator" and "Walk the Line." What is the name of this talented actor?

In 2009, Patrick Kane was arrested in this city, his hometown, for punching a taxi driver. Scott Norwood's "wide right" kick is one focus of a documentary about the four consecutive Super Bowl losses by this city's NFL team. This city's Anchor Bar is the birthplace of a recipe for a deep-fried snack covered in Frank's RedHot sauce and usually dipped in blue cheese. Name this home city of the NFL's Bills and a spicy form of chicken wings.

This structure, shaped like a bowl, consists of four bones: the sacrum, coccyx, and two hip bones (each made of the ilium, ischium, and pubis). It protects vital organs like the bladder and reproductive organs, and it's essential for weight-bearing and locomotion. In females, it's wider and shallower than in males, facilitating childbirth. What is this skeletal structure, often referred to as the "hip bone"?

This mountain is a dormant volcano with three distinct volcanic cones: Shira, Kibo, and Mawenzi. The mountain's slopes are home to diverse ecosystems, ranging from tropical rainforests to alpine deserts, and it's a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This majestic landmark, located in Tanzania, is the highest peak in Africa, towering at 19,341 feet above sea level. Name this iconic mountain, a popular destination for climbers and adventurers seeking to reach its summit, Uhuru Peak.

This team, which made it to the World Series in 2023 but ultimately fell to the Texas Rangers, achieved a significant milestone in 2001 by becoming the fastest expansion team in MLB history to win a World Series. Their home stadium, Chase Field, features a retractable roof and a swimming pool in the outfield. Their mascot is D. Baxter the Bobcat, a playful and energetic feline friend. What is the name of this team, whose distinctive colors are Sedona Red, Sonoran Sand, and Teal?

This dystopian novel, set in a futuristic World State where happiness is prioritized over individuality, features a caste system where citizens are artificially created and conditioned to fit predetermined roles. The characters, including Bernard Marx and Lenina Crowne, navigate a society where conformity is enforced through the use of a happiness drug called "soma" and promiscuity is encouraged. What is the title of this influential novel by Aldous Huxley?
