The Doberai Peninsula is in this nation's easternmost province, and the city of Pontianak in its province of West Kalimantan lies on an island shared by two other countries. The Lombok and Sunda Straits are major shipping lanes in the south of this country, and Bali is a major resort island here. Including the islands of Sumatra and Java name this primarily Muslim archipelagic nation with capital Jakarta.

In August 2024, a US federal court ruled that this tech giant illegally maintained a monopoly and engaged in anti-competitive practices to suppress rivals. The case was brought by the Department of Justice, which argued that the company's dominance stifled innovation and harmed consumers. The case involved this company's rumored mutl-billion dollar payments to Apple and other tech companies to be the default search engine on their devices/platforms. Which tech giant is this?

One of these animals named Elsey tells Maureen that "in Cyberland we only drink Diet Coke" in the musical RENT. In an Irish myth, Cuchulainn is unable to prevent one of these animals from being stolen in a famous "raid of Cooley." In Into the Woods, one of these named Milky White is Jack's only friend. A "pox" of these animals was the source of the first vaccines. Name this common bovine animal which chews its cud and produces milk.

This artist's iconic music video, directed by John Landis and released in 1983, revolutionized the music industry with its elaborate choreography, special effects, and cinematic storytelling. The Thriller video, which runs for over 13 minutes, features a zombie dance sequence that has become a cultural phenomenon, and its album of the same name remains the best-selling album of all time. Who is this artist, also known for his signature moonwalk dance move and chart-topping hits like "Billie Jean" and "Beat It"?

A 9th century holder of this position named Formosus had his corpse put on trial. A holder of this position allied with Philip II and Charles V to fight the Ottomans at Lepanto. Julius II was labeled the"warrior" one of these people after he formed the Holy League. The Council of Clermont was called by another of these men, Urban II, who launched the First Crusade to capture Jerusalem. Name this head of the Catholic Church.

The would-be assassin of this person clashed with his attorney, Judy Clarke, when told his target survived. She received a standing ovation from Congress when she appeared to cast a vote in August 2011. Less than 7 months earlier, she was fighting for her life, after being shot in the head by Jared Loughner in a Safeway parking lot. Name this Arizona congresswoman who resigned her office in January 2012.

In AC circuits, this quantity's namesake right triangle can be used to find its "apparent" form. Intensity is equal to this quantity over area. In an electrical circuit, this quantity can be expressed as voltage squared over resistance, though it is more commonly denoted as current squared time resistance or current times voltage. Name this physical quantity, the amount of work done per unit time, measured in Watts.

This team's iconic orange and black colors, adopted in 1947, were inspired by the owner Horace Stoneham's love of hunting and fishing. They hold the record for the most National League pennants, with 23, and have played in 20 World Series. Their home stadium, Oracle Park, boasts stunning views of their local bay and is known for its signature splash hits into McCovey Cove. Which team, originally based in New York, moved to San Francisco in 1958 and has won eight World Series championships?

This quarterback's iconic pre-snap routine, often involving audibles and elaborate hand signals, earned him the nickname "The Sheriff."  He played college football at University of Tennessee winning the Davey O'Brien award as a senior en route to victory in the 1997 SEC Championship Game. He played for the Indianapolis Colts for 14 seasons and the Denver Broncos for four, winning Super Bowls with both teams.  Who is this legendary quarterback, known for his football intelligence and leadership skills?

In one excerpt from this book the protagonist is told of "two witnesses" who will "prophesy for 1260 days" before being killed and resurrected. In one scene from this work trumpets are given to seven angels, and it begins with the protagonist addressing the seven churches of Asia. In the sixth chapter of this book a lamb begins opening seven seals, the first four of which contain the horseman of the apocalypse. A description of New Jerusalem is given at the conclusion of this work, which consists primarily of a prophetic vision seen by John of Patmos. Name this final book of the Bible.

This neo-noir mystery thriller, directed by Bryan Singer and written by Christopher McQuarrie, follows a group of criminals brought together for a police lineup who subsequently plan a heist. It features an ensemble cast including Kevin Spacey, Gabriel Byrne, and Benicio del Toro, and is known for its complex plot twists and unreliable narrator. Which film, whose ending reveals the true identity of the enigmatic Keyser Söze, is this?

Barry Marshall won a Nobel Prize for his research on this organ, in which he drank a bacteria called H. pylori and discovering that it caused ulcers to form in it. This organ creates chyme out of molecules that arrive from the esophagus to it. A layer of mucus helps protect this organ from the hydrochloric acid that breaks apart proteins before they enter the intestines. Name this digestive organ that breaks down food.

This man was named the Vice Presidential candidate for Kamala Harris's presidential ticket. Before he was a poltician this man served in the Army National Guard and worked as an educator and football coach. He was elected 5 times to the House of Representatives from Minnesota before he was elected the state's governor in 2018. Name this politician who recently gained recognition for calling Donald Trump "weird."

As a British colony, this state was the only one to ban the importing of slaves. John Marshall ruled in a case filed by Samuel Worcester against this state that the Cherokee could not be expelled by state governments, a ruling ignored by Andrew Jackson. This state was founded as a buffer between the British colonies and Spanish territory to the south. Name this state, a debtor's colony founded by James Oglethorpe, who chose its first capital, Savannah.

The Ellsworth Mountains in this landmass are bounded to the north by the Bellingshausen Sea. The Russian-owned Vostok Station can be found in Princess Elizabeth Land in this continent. Vinson Massif is its highest point, and it is the largest desert in the world. Name this continent where the Earth's coldest air temperatures have been recorded, and that contains the South Pole.

This man used missi dominici to investigate his lands. Pope Adrian I asked him to conquer the Lombards early in his reign, and his attempts to eradicate the Moors ended with an unsuccessful attempt to capture Saragossa. This man was served by men such as his tutor Alcuin and his biographer Einhard. The son of Pepin the Short, this man had his lands divided into three parts at the Treaty of Verdun. He was crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Leo III on Christmas Day in the year 800 A.D. Name this member of the Carolignian dynasty, a leader of the Franks.

This gymnast recently secured her eighth all-around title at the 2023 U.S. Gymnastics Championships, further cementing her status as the most decorated gymnast in U.S. history. She made a triumphant return to competitive gymnastics after a two-year hiatus, having withdrawn from several events during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics to prioritize her mental health. At the 2024 Paris Olympics, she became the oldest U.S. woman to win an individual Olympic medal in gymnastics since 1952. Who is this inspiring athlete, known for her groundbreaking skills and advocacy for mental health awareness?

Paintings of this type by Frida Kahlo include ones "with Cropped Hair" and "with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird". Norman Rockwell created a "triple" painting of this type. Vincent Van Gogh created one of these paintings in which his bandaged ear is visible. These paintings became easier to create with the advent of mirrors. Name this artistic genre in which a painter depicts themself.

This television series' final season was met with mixed reviews and a petition signed by over a million viewers demanding a remake. The show's opening credits feature a 3D map of the fictional continents where the story takes place, Westeros and Essos. Based on George R. R. Martin's book series "A Song of Ice and Fire," this fantasy drama is known for its complex characters, intricate plotlines, and shocking twists. What is the name of this popular HBO series?

Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of this nation resigned and fled the country after huge student protests over the nation's quota system. The protests resulted in hundreds of deaths, the resignation of the prime minister, and the dissolution of her government. The 2006 Nobel Peace Prize winner, Muhammad Yunus, was selected to form an interim government until elections can be held. What is this nation which is one of the most densely populated in the world and has an official language of Bengali?

The London equations can be used to describe the magnetic fields of these objects. In a solid state, these materials come in LCO or YBCO forms. The London penetration depth, studied by John Schrieffer, is the depth a magnetic field penetrates these types of materials. According to BCS theory, below the Fermi level they form Cooper pairs through electron-phonon interactions. These objects expel their internal magnetic field by the Meissner effect. Name these objects which have no electrical resistance.

Erich Von Daniken claimed the sarcophagus of a king of these people depicts an astronaut riding a rocket. These people built the early observatory of El Caracol, and made human sacrifices in cenotes. King Pacal of these people was born on 9.8.9.13.0 in this people's "Long Count" calendar. These people were the first to develop the idea of zero, and they wrote in a hieroglyphic language found at Palenque. Chichen Itza was built by what pre-Columbian civilization of the Yucatan Peninsula and Guatemala?

Awaji, a small island in this nation, is known for the fine quality of its onions. One island in this country contains Lake Biwa, which is drained by the Yodo River into the Inland Sea; that island is also home to the Hida and Akaishi mountain ranges. This country suffered a devastating earthquake and tsunami near its Fukushima region, nearly causing a nuclear disaster. The Kanto plain is located in this land of the rising sun whose four main islands are Shikoku, Kyushu, Hokkaido, and Honshu.

This king's wife scraped wax off a tablet sent by Demartus to uncover a hidden message. The 400 Thebans accompanying this man at his most notable engagement largely surrendered to enemy forces. Ephialtes betrayed this husband of Queen Gorgo by identifying a path around his forces. This king responded "come and take them" upon being ordered to surrender his weapons at a location nicknamed the "hot gates." Name this Spartan king who fought in the Battle of Thermopylae with his 300 soldiers.

In Amonton's Laws, the effect of this force is independent of surface area. This force's magnitude is equal to a namesake coefficient, symbolized mu, times the normal force. One type of this force prevents resting objects from sliding and can be overcome with lubricants. Name this force that opposes motion between bodies in contact.

A yellow ribbon symbolizes the independence movement of a region in this country. The cantera policy of a soccer team in this country to only use local players emphasizes Basque pride. Architecture designed by Antoni Gaudi is prominent in this country's region of Catalonia, and especially the city of Barcelona. Name this country formed by the union of Castile and Aragon whose capital is Madrid.

This historical group worshipped the son of Coatlicue, who was impregnated by a ball of feathers. These Nahuatl-speaking people worshipped a "left-handed" or "southern" hummingbird, Huitzilopochtli, and a rain god named Tlaloc in a pair of temples perched on top of a pyramidal platform. Name these people who worshiped gods like Quetzalcoatl in the Templo Mayor in Tenochtitlan before they were conquered by Hernan Cortes.

This team's distinctive pirate logo, featuring a silver and black eye patch-wearing man, was designed by Allen "Skip" Davis in 1963. Originally based in Oakland, California, they relocated to Los Angeles in 1982 and then to Las Vegas in 2020. They have won three Super Bowl championships (XI, XV, and XVIII) and one AFL championship in 1967.  Which NFL team's motto, "Just win, baby," was coined by longtime owner Al Davis?

Moses Rose is legendarily considered the "coward" of this battle. William Travis was left in sole command because the volunteer leader was bedridden, and Susanna Dickinson was spared to warn others of the defeat. Ending on March 6, 1836 with the deaths of James Bowie, Davy Crockett, and roughly 200 others in a San Antonio mission name this disastrous battle of the Texas Revolution.

A town in this nation became the focus of national attention in July 2024 following a tragic stabbing spree that sparked a wave of protests and unrest across the country. The incident occurred during a children's dance class, resulting in the deaths of three young girls and injuries to several others. The subsequent spread of misinformation and exploitation of the event by far-right groups fueled anti-immigrant demonstrations and violence. Southport known for its beaches and Victorian architecture, is a part of which country?

This musician's real name is Richard Starkey, and he was born in Liverpool, England, in 1940. His solo career has spanned decades, and he has released numerous albums and singles, including hits like "Photograph" and "It Don't Come Easy." He is also an accomplished actor and voice actor, known for his roles in films like "Caveman" and "Thomas & Friends." He joined the Beatles in 1962, replacing their original drummer, Pete Best. Who is this iconic drummer and multi-talented performer?

This thinker's early work The Birth of Tragedy discusses the Apollonian and Dionysian elements in Greek tragedy. This thinker's work On the Genealogy of Morality accuses Christianity of encouraging weakness, and his criticism continued in The Antichrist. A Persian prophet describes the Ubermensch in Thus Spoke Zarathustra by what German philosopher whose work was embraced by the Nazis?

This American military officer controversially kept Emperor Hirohito from facing war crimes trials, and helped write the constitution of Japan. During the Korean War, he had wanted to cross the Yalu River to attack the Chinese, and was eventually removed from command after trying to drum up support for this offensive in Congress. He also was in charge of removing the Bonus Army from Washington. Name this American general who, during World War II, he rose to the rank of Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in the Southwest Pacific Area.

This artist's final album, released just days before his tragic death, included the Grammy-winning hit "Sexual Healing". He started his musical journey singing in a church choir led by his father, a Pentecostal minister. Known for his smooth vocals and socially conscious lyrics, he recorded timeless classics like "What's Going On" and "Let's Get It On".  Who is this iconic soul singer, whose life was cut short by his own father in a domestic dispute?

This footballer's early career was marked by a growth hormone deficiency, which was treated by FC Barcelona after his family relocated to Spain. He is known for his exceptional dribbling skills, precise passing, and prolific goalscoring, earning him numerous awards and accolades, including a record seven Ballon d'Or titles. He recently made a high-profile move to Inter Miami CF in Major League Soccer, leaving Paris Saint-Germain after two seasons. Who is this Argentine forward, widely regarded as one of the greatest footballers of all time?

An underactive parathyroid gland will cause a low blood level of this substance. The sarcoplasmic reticulum stores ions of this mineral, which is needed for muscle contraction. Vitamin D assists the absorption of both phosphate and this element in the gut. Seniors may take a supplement of this element to prevent osteoporosis, and children often get their intake by drinking milk. Name this element needed to build strong bones and teeth.

In August 2024, a sudden strengthening of this currency, coupled with concerns about a potential recession in the United States, sent shockwaves through global markets. The surge in its value triggered a massive sell-off in Japanese stocks, leading to the Nikkei 225 index suffering its largest single-day point drop in history. This chain reaction ultimately impacted markets across the globe, with major indices like the Dow Jones and S&P 500 experiencing significant declines. What is the name of this currency, whose volatility highlighted the interconnectedness of global financial markets?

This man's secretary, Orville Babcock, and vice president, Schuyler Colfax, were accused in the scandals of the Whiskey Ring and Credit Mobilier. He captured Fort Donelson and opened the Mississippi River at Vicksburg before he was promoted to command all the Union armies and accepted the surrender of Robert E. Lee at Appomattox. Name this Union general and eighteenth President.

A rill is a shallow channel created by water during this process. Terracing can slow down this process on a hillside, while removing trees can speed up this process, as the roots can no longer hold onto the soil. Name this process of transporting material by wind or water.

Members of this faith form houses known as sosyete, and its holy men are sometimes called houngan. It believes in an ancestral homeland of Ginen, worships the supreme being Bondye, and originates in Yoruban myth. The Ogunye and Ezili are families of this religion's spirits, or loa, which include Papa Legba and Baron Samedi. Name this syncretic religion practiced in Louisiana and Haiti, whose rarer practices might involve zombies or pin-filled dolls.

This object reduces transaction costs in an economy by eliminating the requirement for a double conincidence of wants. Gresham's law states that the bad variety of this will drive out the good variety. The Federal Reserve of the United States conducts open market operations in order to change the supply of this object. The rate at which this changes hands is referred to as the velocity of circulation. In the U.S., it became fiat in 1971 under Richard Nixon, and inflation is the devaluation of this. Identify this method of payment whose various forms include traveller's cheques, checkable deposits, and currency in circulation.

This track and field athlete won the gold medal in 100 meters at the 2024 Olympics. He sparked controversy by questioning the use of the term "world champion" for NBA title winners, leading to public exchanges with prominent figures like Kevin Durant and Drake. He then won a bronze medal in the 200 meter race after claiming to have tested positive for COVID two days prior. Who is this outspoken sprinter known for his charismatic personality and impressive speed?

The attempted sale of this man's vacated Senate seat led to the resignation of governor Rod Blagojevich. Following negotiations with Raul Castro, this president became the first to visit Cuba in eighty-eight years. This president, who nominated Merrick Garland, Elena Kagan, and Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court, ended Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan in 2014. Name this U.S. President, the namesake of the Affordable Care Act.

This leader served as the Minister of Information and Broadcasting under Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, whose death led to this person's first term as prime minister. In order to eliminate political rivals, this person instituted a two year state of emergency which would later be the impetus behind this leader's deposing by the Janata Party. This ruler also authorized a test at Pokhran of a nuclear device called Smiling Buddha. Name this Indian Prime Minister who, after authorizing an attack on the Golden Temple of Amritsar known as Operation Blue Star, was assassinated in 1984 by two of her Sikh bodyguards.

This team's iconic ballpark, Camden Yards, opened in 1992 and is often credited with sparking a wave of retro-style stadium construction across Major League Baseball. Their mascot is named after the state bird of Maryland. Cal Ripken Jr., known for breaking Lou Gehrig's consecutive games played record, spent his entire 21-year career with this team. What is the name of this team, whose distinctive black and orange colors represent Baltimore's city flag?

In this novel, Pope Urban X's daughter cuts off her buttock to serve to soldiers in a siege. Cacambo explores El Dorado with a man who says, "we must cultivate our garden" at the end of this novel. After an attack on Castle Thunder-ten-Tronckh, this novel's protagonist struggles to reunite with his lover, Cunegonde, and his teacher, Doctor Pangloss, who insists that "all is for the best in this best of all possible worlds."Name this satirical French novel about a title "Optimist," written by Voltaire.

Copper and saltpeter mining in this desert contribute to the economy of cities like Iquique and Antofagasta. In this desert, fog clouds called camanchacas are formed by the nearby Humboldt Current, forming a temperature inversion that enables native plants to survive its conditions. Because of the rain shadow of the Andes Mountains to its east, this desert is considered the driest on Earth. Name this desert, located mostly in Chile.

This iconic sitcom initially titled "Insomnia Cafe," followed the lives of six friends navigating their twenties and thirties in New York City. It featured a memorable opening sequence filmed at the Warner Bros. Ranch in Burbank, California, and its theme song, "I'll Be There for You" by The Rembrandts, became an instant hit. The series finale, aired in 2004, remains one of the most-watched television episodes in history. Which sitcom,  which aired for ten seasons from 1994 to 2004,, is this?

In one story by this author, the homeless Soapy unsuccessfully tries to get himself arrested to avoid the cold. This author of "The Cop and the Anthem" also wrote about two men's kidnapping of Ebenezer Dorset, which fails when they have to pay his father to take his son back. "The Ransom of Red Chief" is by what American author of short stories such as "The Gift of the Magi"?

The size of these natural phenomena is determined by the "fetch" behind them. When these things "break," they release kinetic energy as matter falls from its maximum amplitude. These phenomena may "shoal" in shallow water, and they do not occur when there is no wind. Name this physical phenomenon, a rippling motion on the surface of a body of water.

This physical educator was a Canadian-American physician who invented a sport in 1891 while working at the YMCA International Training School in Springfield, Massachusetts. He initially used peach baskets as goals, requiring a ladder to retrieve a ball after each score. Often called the "Father of Basketball," he served as the first coach at the University of Kansas. Who was this sports innovator, whose creation has become a beloved global pastime?

This aerospace giant's CST-100 Starliner spacecraft, intended to transport astronauts to and from the International Space Station, encountered multiple technical problems during its June 2024 test flight, including propellant leaks and thruster failures. These issues left two NASA astronauts stranded on the ISS, potentially delaying their return to Earth until late 2024 or early 2025. What is this company that is best known for their airplanes?

Tennessee politician Harry Burn cast the deciding vote for this amendment. The Silent Sentinels, including Lucy Burns and Alice Paul, protested in favor of this amendment in front of the White House and were tortured by police in 1917. Carrie Chapman Catt led the National American Woman Suffrage Association, which advocated for what Constitutional amendment that guaranteed women the right to vote?
answers: Ninetennth Amendment to the US Constitution

question: This neo-western thriller, based on the 2005 novel of the same name by Cormac McCarthy, features Javier Bardem as Anton Chigurh, a ruthless hitman with a distinctive hairstyle and a captive bolt pistol. Set in the Texas desert in 1980, the story revolves around a hunter, Llewelyn Moss, who stumbles upon a drug deal gone wrong and takes the money. He soon finds himself pursued by Chigurh, leading to a cat-and-mouse chase across the desolate landscape. What is the title of this 2007 film directed by the Coen brothers?

The first prime minister of this country gave a speech outlining the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence that formed a basis for a treaty with China, and he also gave the "Tryst with Destiny" speech. Another prime minister was assassinated by her bodyguards in 1984 soon after approving an attack on the Golden Temple in Amritsar. Name this country once headed by Jawaharlal Nehru that disputes the status of Kashmir with Pakistan.

The MKAD and the Garden Ring are both ring roads circling this city. A Hilton Hotel and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building are skyscrapers among this city's "seven sisters." A church in this city is shaped like a flame, contains nine side churches around a main Church of Intercession, and is known for its brightly colored onion domes. Gorky Park and the GUM department store are in this city home to St. Basil's Cathedral. Red Square and the Kremlin are in what capital of Russia?

This team, originally based in Chicago and known as the Packers, relocated to Baltimore in 1951 and became the Bullets.  After a move to the nation's capital in 1973, they changed their name to reflect the city's heritage. Their most successful era came in the 1970s when they won their only NBA championship in 1978 led by Wes Unseld and Elvin Hayes. What is the name of this team that plays in Capital One Arena?

Schedar is the brightest of its five stars. The Perseid meteor shower originates between Perseus and this constellation, which is visible year-round in the northern hemisphere. Its W shape represents a seated mythological queen. Identify this constellation named for the mother of Andromeda.

In response to a question from Chaerephon, the Pythian oracle stated that no one was wiser than this philosopher, who claimed to know that he knew nothing. This "gadfly of the state" said that an "unexamined life is not worth living" while being sentenced to drink hemlock for corrupting the youth of Athens, as described in his student's Apology. Name this Greek philosopher, a predecessor of Aristotle, whose "dialogues"were recorded by Plato after his death.

This body of water is home to Antelope Island, which becomes Antelope Peninsula when the water level dips too low. This body of water lies in what was, 30,000 years ago, Lake Bonneville. This body of water has no river outflows and only loses water via evaporation, causing its high salinity. This body of water lies just west of Brigham City and northwest of a namesake state capital. Name this largest body of water in Utah.

This man used powers granted by the Taft-Hartley Act during a confrontation with air traffic controllers, and his Defense Secretary resigned after violations of the Boland Amendment were revealed. Before those events during his presidency, he served as Governor of California from 1967 until 1975. Prior to entering politics, this man was a famous Hollywood actor. Name this Republican president from 1981 to 1989.

Despite being diagnosed with melanoma in 1977, this musician refused amputation due to his religious beliefs, ultimately succumbing to the disease in 1981. This musician's iconic song, "One Love/People Get Ready," became an anthem of peace and unity, blending his original lyrics with those of a Curtis Mayfield song. He was a devout Rastafarian, whose dreadlocks and use of marijuana were central to his spiritual and artistic identity. Who was this legendary reggae musician?

This conflict is the basis for the novel The Road Back, a sequel to another novel set during this conflict which centers on one of the students of Kantorek. One poem written about this conflict exclaims "Gas! Gas! Quick Boys!", while another poem about this war describes the place where poppies blow, between the crosses, row on row, in Flanders, Belgium. The author of "Dulce et Decorum Est," Wilfred Owen, died during what global conflict which was most famously depicted through the eyes of Paul Baumer in All Quiet on the Western Front?
answers: The War to End All Wars

question: This European city was set to host three sold-out concerts by a global pop star in August 2024, but the shows were abruptly cancelled due to security concerns. The cancellation came after Austrian authorities arrested two individuals suspected of planning a terrorist attack targeting the concert venue. This city is the fifth most populous in the European Union and is Austria's primate city. Which city, known for its rich musical heritage and iconic concert halls, was this?

The prime minister of this nation announced he would step down in September 2024. The governing Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will elect the leader to succeed Fumio Kishida as prime minister. This country's LDP has been in power for most of the postwar period, with brief interruptions. The national government features a bicameral parliament called the National Diet, consisting of the House of Representatives and the House of Councillors. Though a constitutional monarchy, its Emperor holds a largely ceremonial role. Which Asian country is this, known for its unique blend of tradition and modernity?

This operation is applied to the number five in the golden ratio, and when this operation is applied to two, the result is an irrational number approximately equal to "one point four one four." The length of the hypotenuse is found by applying this operation to both sides of the Pythagorean Theorem. Raising a value to the one-half exponent is equivalent to performing this operation. A radical sign indicates what operation that, when applied to twenty-five, gives five?

Cross-dressing men in this country are often referred to by the term kathoey, or "ladyboy." This country's Isan region includes the Khorat Plateau, which is bounded by Phetchabun Range. Patong Beach is on this country's largest island, which lies in the Andaman Sea west of the Isthmus of Kra. Phuket is a resort area in this country separated from Laos by the Mekong River. Chiang Mai and Ayutthaya are cities in what country ruled by Rama X from Bangkok?

All four canonical gospels identify a person with this name as the first person to witness both Jesus's empty tomb and his resurrection. Another person of this name was chided by her sister Martha for not preparing the house for Jesus's visit. A person of this name is the subject of the Magnificat as well as the dogmas of her Assumption and Immaculate Conception. Give this name of the wife of Joseph, who is also the mother of Jesus.

This track and field athlete's record-breaking long jump of 8.95 meters at the 1991 World Championships in Tokyo stood for over three decades. He won nine Olympic gold medals, including four consecutive golds in the long jump from 1984 to 1996. He also achieved the remarkable feat of winning four Olympic gold medals in a single Olympics, mirroring Jesse Owens' achievement in 1936. Name this athlete who was selected as "Sportsman of the Century" by the International Olympic Committee, "Olympian of the Century" by Sports Illustrated.

This long-running animated sitcom features a talking baby bent on world domination and a dog who enjoys martinis and intellectual pursuits. Created by Seth MacFarlane, this show is set in the fictional town of Quahog, Rhode Island, and follows the misadventures of the Griffin family. It's known for its satirical humor, cutaway gags, and frequent pop culture references. Name this show that has been canceled and revived multiple times, and its controversial content has often sparked debate and criticism.

Two of these works written by Rabindranath Tagore are "Amar Sonar Banglar" and "Jana Gana Mana". After declaring war on Austria, de Lisle composed one of these titled "La Marseillaise", while Britain's inability to seize Fort McHenry inspired one of these works by Francis Scott Key. Name these pieces composed for countries, which include "God Save the Queen" and "The Star-Spangled Banner."

In this musical, Chulalongkorn disputes the size of his home country on a map after a royal governess sings "Getting to Know You." In this musical, the slave girl Tuptim writes a play based on Uncle Tom's Cabin, and the female lead sings "Shall We Dance" while teaching Mongkut to do the polka. Name this Rodgers & Hammerstein musical about Anna Leonowens and the King of Siam.

Opposite corners of this constellation are at Saiph and Bellatrix. Though called its beta, its brightest star is usually Rigel. This constellation is visible only in the winter, and its alpha star, part of the Winter Triangle and at the center of the Winter Hexagon, is Betelgeuse. A line across its center formed by Alnitak, Alnilam, and Mintaka is known as its "belt". Name this constellation known as the Hunter.

According to the Koran, all angels, except Satan, prostrated themselves before this figure due to his knowledge. He was cursed to "eat bread until he returned to the ground." In the New Testament, he is seen as the source of death for all men. His transgression is revealed to God when he is seen wearing a fig leaf. His rib was used to make his wife, Eve. Name this Biblical figure, the first man.

The Tanami Desert is located within this nation, and its extreme north is known as Arnhem Land, which is separated from the Cape York Peninsula by the Gulf of Carpentaria. Two states within this nation are separated by the Bass Strait, and its longest river, the Murray, forms just west of Mt. Kosciuszko. The lowest point in this nation is also at its largest body of water, Lake Eyre. Tasmania is the southernmost state of what island nation that borders the Great Barrier Reef and features such cities as Brisbane and Sydney?

This country's parliament elected their youngest prime minister on August 16, 2024. Paetongtarn Shinawatra, a member of a prominent political family, still needs to be endorsed by King Maha Vajiralongkorn before she can officially take office. This nation's flag features two white stripes, a central blue stripe, and two red stripes. It is home to the world's largest solid gold Buddha statue, weighing 5.5 tons. Name this country that is famous for its cuisine including Tom Yung Goong and Pad Thai.

This musician formed the band Wings after The Beatles disbanded, and their hit "Mull of Kintyre" became the first single to sell over two million copies in the UK. He co-wrote the song "Yesterday," which holds the record for the most covered song in history.  Knighted in 1997 for his services to music, he's known for his iconic left-handed Höfner bass guitar. Who is this legendary songwriter and musician?

Admiral Seiichi Ito attempted to launch Ten-go sakusen during this battle, but his battleship Yamoto was sunk before it could be accomplished. The Japanese retreated to the Kiyan Peninsula at the later stages, and earlier Major General Pedro del Valle had captured the Shuri Castle. Kamikaze tactics employed by the Japanese caused the greatest casualties in this battle than any other battle of the war. Also known as "Operation Iceberg" and the "Typhoon of Steel," identify this naval battle fought from April 1st to June 23 of 1945 that served as the last stop of Allies island hopping?

While holding this position, Alexander Haig incorrectly claimed that he was "in control here" after the shooting of Ronald Reagan. In the aftermath of the sinking of the Lusitania, William Jennings Bryan left this position. Madeleine Albright, the first woman to hold this post, urged future holder Colin Powell to intervene in Bosnia. Anthony Blinken currently holds what US Cabinet post in charge of foreign affairs?

A native of Bethesda, Maryland, she began swimming competitively at a young age and quickly rose to prominence, breaking numerous age-group records. This swimmer's dominance in the 800-meter freestyle is unparalleled, having claimed victory at four consecutive Olympic Games from 2012 to 2024. She holds multiple world records in various freestyle events, including the 400m, 800m, and 1500m distances. Who is this athlete, often referred to as the greatest female swimmer of all time?

This man defeated King Porus at the Battle of the Hydaspes. After that battle, this man founded a city in India named for his horse Bucephalus. This man's generals, the Diadochi, divided his empire after his death. This man defeated Darius III at Issus and Gaugamela, ending the Achaemenid Persian empire. This man was the son of Philip II of Macedon, and he was tutored by Aristotle. Name this leader known as "the Great."

TThis athlete holds the record for the most consecutive weeks at number one in the Official World Golf Ranking, an astonishing 281 weeks. He famously won the 1997 Masters Tournament by a record-breaking 12 strokes, becoming the youngest-ever champion at age 21. His 15 major championships rank second all-time, trailing only Jack Nicklaus. He held all four major titles simultaneously, a feat unmatched in modern golf. Who is this iconic golfer, known for his red and black Sunday outfits?

The Garigal and Lane Cove national parks are in this city, whose center is known as the Circular Quay. It is located on the south shore of Port Jackson, which is spanned by a namesake Harbour Bridge. Jorn Utzon designed the white shells of this city's opera house. Suburbs of this city can be found on the coast of Botany Bay. Name this city on the coast of New South Wales, the largest in Australia.

This American mockumentary sitcom, based on a British series of the same name, follows the daily lives of employees at a paper company in Scranton, Pennsylvania.  The show's main character, Michael Scott, is the regional manager, known for his cringe-inducing humor and misguided attempts to be liked by his employees. What is the title of this show, which originally aired from 2005 to 2013 and gained even greater popularity through streaming services?

One poet from this country wrote that "each man kills the thing he loves" after being jailed for homosexuality. Another poet from this non-African country wrote "things fall apart; the centre cannot hold" in "The Second Coming". Jonathan Swift suggested this country's residents sell babies for food in the satire A Modest Proposal. What country produced W. B. Yeats and Sean O'Casey?

This disease, once primarily associated with Central and West Africa, saw a global outbreak in 2022, leading the World Health Organization to declare it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. It is transmitted through close contact with infected individuals, animals, or contaminated materials. Symptoms include fever, rash, and swollen lymph nodes. What is this disease, which seen increased infection levels in 2024, formerly known as monkeypox?

This state has the fewest members in its state legislature; it is also the only state with a unicameral one. It was the northern of two territories mentioned in an 1854 act introducing popular sovereignty. The western part of this state contains Chimney Rock. When it became a state in 1867 it renamed its capital after a recently assassinated president. Name this state whose largest city is Omaha.

This disease causes Brushfield spots on the iris, and sufferers of this disease are at risk for early-onset Alzheimer's. Symptoms of this disease include epicanthic eye folds and an enlarged, wrinkled tongue. This disease is caused by a trisomy on chromosome 21. This disease is more common in the offspring of mothers over 40. Name this syndrome, a genetic disorder that results in developmental delays.

In this state, preserved remains of woolly mammoths are found in the La Brea Tar Pits. This state is home to General Sherman, the largest tree in the world and one of many redwoods located in Sequoia National Park. Its Sierra Nevada mountain range runs through Yosemite National Park. Name this state located directly south of Oregon which contains the Sacramento River and San Francisco Bay.

This figure is a patron of potters according to a minor cult in Athens. This figure, whose name means "Forethought" in Greek, is honored in a precursor to the Olympic torch relay. This figure tricked Zeus by wrapping ox bones in fat, setting a precedent for animal sacrifices. After he was exiled to the Caucasus by Zeus, Heracles killed this figure's tormentor, an eagle who ate his liver after it regenerated daily. Name this Titan and brother of Epimetheus who stole fire from the gods and gave it to humans.

This film swept the five major categories at the 64th Academy Awards, a rare feat in cinematic history. Its iconic line, "A census taker once tried to test me...," is delivered by the brilliant but manipulative antagonist. The chilling scene of Buffalo Bill dancing to "Goodbye Horses" has become a haunting image in pop culture. Jodie Foster stars as Clarice Starling, a young FBI trainee tasked with interviewing Hannibal Lecter to gain insights into the mind of a serial killer. What is the title of this psychological thriller?

This man lamented "It is well that war is so terrible, or we should grow too fond of it" during his victory over Ambrose Burnside at the Battle of Fredericksburg. This man, who led the militia that ended John Brown's raid, was victorious at the Second Battle of Bull Run. Name this general who, on April 9th, 1865, surrendered his Confederate army at Appomattox to Ulysses S. Grant.

This iconic athlete's famous nickname is an Italian term for "baby." He initially started his career as a pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, winning three World Series titles before being controversially sold to the New York Yankees in 1919. This move sparked the so-called "Curse of the Bambino," which supposedly plagued the Red Sox for 86 years until they finally won another World Series in 2004. Name this athlete that retired in 1935, but his record of 714 career home runs stood for nearly 40 years until it was broken by Hank Aaron in 1974.

Individuals were recently arrested related to this man's death in October 2023. He was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for his guest role on "The West Wing." This actor's memoir, "Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing," candidly details his struggles with addiction and his journey to sobriety. He is most celebrated for his iconic role as the witty and sarcastic Chandler Bing in the beloved sitcom "Friends." Who is this actor?

One ruler from this place was the wife of France's Louis XIII, Anne. Another Archduke of this place issued the Patent of Toleration. That ruler's mother came to power after the issuing of the Pragmatic Sanction, was the mother of Marie Antoinette, and ruled during a war of succession named after this country; those rulers were Joseph II and Maria Theresa. Name this country where the Habsburgs ruled from Vienna.

This mineral is at the bottom of Bowen's reaction series, and its piezoelectric properties make it useful as a component of crystal oscillators. Common varieties of this second most common mineral in Earth's crust include citrine, amethyst, and onyx. This mineral is the largest component of granite and is primarily composed of silicon dioxide. Name this mineral with a Mohs hardness of 7.

This footballer, known for his incredible goalscoring prowess, set a new Premier League record in his debut season by netting an astonishing 36 goals. He was born in Leeds, England, while his father, Alfie, was playing for Leeds United. He started his professional career at the Norwegian club Bryne FK and later gained international recognition during his stints at Red Bull Salzburg and Borussia Dortmund. Currently, he plays for Manchester City, where he continues to break records and dazzle fans with his clinical finishing and powerful presence. Who is this prolific striker?

This nation overthrew Albania's King Zog. A major event in the unification of this nation was the Expedition of the Thousand, and its first king after unification was Victor Emanuel II. In 1935 this nation invaded Ethiopia. One of its leaders was called Il Duce, and along with Germany, it was one of Europe's major Axis powers. Name this European country that was ruled by fascist dictator Benito Mussolini.

This show originally aired on Fox, but it was revived on ABC in 2018. The phrase "Seacrest out!" became a catchphrase associated with its long-time host. The show's inaugural season saw Kelly Clarkson emerge victorious, defeating Justin Guarini in the finale. Its iconic trio of judges, Simon Cowell, Paula Abdul, and Randy Jackson, became synonymous with the show's early success. What is the name of this popular singing competition show?

In Sikhism, a Dastar protects this substance, which is called Kesh and tended with a Kangha, two of the Five K's. Payot are a variety of this substance worn in Orthodox Judaism, and some Muslims cover this substance with a hijab. Samson derived his strength from this substance, and became weak when Delilah cut it. Name this substance that grows out of human heads and faces.

The Laguerre polynomial gives the radial part of the state vector for this element that has a namesake line that forms when it transitions between two ground level states, called its "twenty-one centimeter line." All of its visible spectral lines are within the Balmer series, and it has an isotope with two more neutrons than normal that is called tritium. It also has a "heavy" form that is called deuterium. Name this lightest element, the most abundant in the universe, with chemical symbol H.

At its delta, this river splits into Rosetta and Damietta branches. This river exits Lake Victoria at the site of the submerged Ripon Falls. The Lake Tana-sourced river "Blue" version of this river converges with its "White" version at Khartoum. The building of the Aswan High Dam on this river ended its flooding in one country and created Lake Nasser. The Giza Plateau's namesake Great Pyramid lies on the west bank of this river. Name this African river that empties into the Mediterranean Sea and flows through Cairo, Egypt, the world's longest.

This annual end-of-summer event is governed by 10 principles, including radical self-reliance, gifting, and leaving no trace. Participants create a temporary city, Black Rock City in the Nevada desert, filled with art installations, theme camps, and interactive experiences. What is the name of this unique event that culminates in the burning of a large wooden effigy, symbolizing a ritual farewell to the past?

While aboard the USS Abraham Lincoln, this man gave a speech while a banner reading "mission accomplished" hung in the background. In another speech, this man claimed that North Korea was part of an "Axis of Evil." This president was criticized for continuing to read "My Pet Goat" after he was informed of an attack on the World Trade Center. Name this President of the United States who declared war after the September 11th attacks.

This ruler launched an invasion of Gaul after Honoria sent him a ring, but it was put down on the Catalaunian Plains by Flavius Aetius. A year after this man lost the Battle of Chalons, Pope Leo I convinced this man to spare his city. According to legend, this man died of a nosebleed. He crossed the Danube twice and plundered the Balkans but was unable to take Constantinople. Rome was nearly sacked by what 5th century ruler of the Huns?

This city is home to the Institute for Advanced Study, where Albert Einstein worked after moving to the US. Hugh Mercer was mortally wounded during a Revolutionary War battle over this city that took place a week after Washington surprised the Hessians by crossing the Delaware River. Since 1945, this college town has been its state's governor's residence, rather than the state capital of Trenton. Name this town that is home to New Jersey's only Ivy League university.

This film series' iconic vehicles include the Interceptor, a modified Ford Falcon XB GT coupe, and the monstrous Gigahorse truck. The post-apocalyptic setting, characterized by a desert wasteland, is a franchise hallmark. The protagonist, Max Rockatansky, is a former police officer turned lone wanderer. Its groundbreaking practical stunts and visual effects have influenced countless action films. What is the name of this franchise, with a recent prequel, "Furiosa"?

This US city played host to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. This city is home to the world's first skyscraper, the ten-story Home Insurance Building, built in 1885. It also boasts the iconic Cloud Gate sculpture, affectionately known as "The Bean," in Millennium Park. The city's river is famously dyed green every St. Patrick's Day. Additionally, it is the birthplace of deep-dish pizza, a culinary delight loved by many. What is the name of this city, often called the "Windy City"?

This athlete's rivalry with Larry Bird, which began in college, captivated the nation and fueled the NBA's popularity in the 1980s. He famously played all five positions in Game 6 of the 1980 NBA Finals, leading his team to a championship and earning the Finals MVP award as a rookie. He shocked the world in 1991 when he announced his retirement from basketball after testing positive for HIV. However, he made a triumphant return to the sport, winning a gold medal with the "Dream Team" at the Barcelona Olympics. Who is this legendary Laker, known by his iconic nickname?

One chytrid member of this group has been blamed for the worldwide decline in frog populations, and the Salem witch trials have been blamed on another species that infests rye with ergot. Lichens consist of algae and a member of this kingdom, whose species reproduce through spores and have hyphae bodies with chitin cell walls. Name this kingdom of important decomposers like molds, yeasts, and mushrooms.

In a novel by this author, Ayesha leads a group of men to drown in the Arabian sea, which features Saladin Chamcha. Another novel by this author, which is narrated by Saleem Sinai, includes a group of characters that were born at the moment of India's independence. In 2022, a attacker stabbed this author in the eye while he was giving a lecture. Name this British-Indian author, who wrote Midnight's Children and The Satanic Verses.

This archipelago in the South Atlantic features a peninsula called Lafonia on its eastern island. Its former capital, located on Grantham Sound, was replaced by Stanley in 1845. The Jason Islands lie northwest of its main group. Also known as las Islas Malvinas, it was the site of a 1982 conflict between Argentina and the United Kingdom. What is the name of this British Overseas Territory?

This artist holds the distinction of being the only person to win an Oscar, Emmy, Grammy, and Tony, as well as a Golden Globe, CableACE Award, and Peabody Award. She made her Broadway debut in the musical "I Can Get It for You Wholesale" in 1962. Her iconic roles in films like "Funny Girl" and "The Way We Were" cemented her status as a Hollywood legend. Beyond acting, she released numerous chart-topping albums throughout her career. Who is this multi-talented entertainer, often referred to by her initials, "Babs"?

During this activity, K-complexes and namesake spindles appear on an electroencephalogram (EEG). Rapid eye movement occurs during this activity, and apnea occurs when people can't breathe while doing it. Narcolepsy can cause people to start this activity unexpectedly. It is divided into REM and non-REM phases. When people have trouble doing this activity it is called insomnia. Name this restorative nighttime activity.

This man recently plead guilty to charges of wire fraud and identity theft. He was elected to the US House of Representatives in 2022 as a Republican from New York becoming the first openly gay Republican elected to Congress. Shortly after this man was elected, news broke that much of his biography was fabricated and he faced calls to resign. Name this man who resigned in disgrace from the House in December 2023.

This man's book A History of the English Speaking Peoples helped to earn him a Nobel Prize in Literature. This man gave a speech in Fulton, Missouri, where he warned of an incoming "Iron Curtain" of Soviet influence. During World War II, this man was a leader of the Grand Alliance along with Joseph Stalin and Franklin Roosevelt. Name this Prime Minister of the United Kingdom during World War II.

Islands in this body of water contain Mount Tomanivi and Mount Talomo, which sits near Davao City on an island near the Sulu Sea. This body of water contains the Yap Trench and the islands of Viti Levu and Mindanao. This large body of water is home to Mount Aso on Kyushu, and to Mauna Loa. Name this ocean, whose "ring of fire" is marked by volcanic activity in the Philippines, Japan, and Hawai'i.

This NFL team, despite its storied history, is one of four teams to have never reached a Super Bowl, yet they boast a proud tradition, having won four NFL Championships prior to the Super Bowl era. Their iconic Honolulu blue and silver uniforms are a familiar sight on the gridiron, and their home, Ford Field, roars with the energy of their devoted fanbase. Which team, once starring Barry Sanders, plays in Detroit?

This god is said to have a rivalry with his first father-in-law, Daksha, because Daksha neglected to invite him to sacrifices. This deity is often depicted with crescent moon on his forehead, and with a third eye that can reduce things to ashes. After cutting off the head of his son because he would not let him in the house to see his wife Parvati, he replaced his son's head with an elephant's head; that son was Ganesha. Name this Hindu deity, often called "the destroyer."

This school of thought argues that we can only control our prohairesis, the choice to respond to seemingly good or bad things. This philosophy, which teaches that true happiness comes from virtue, was promoted in the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius. Zeno of Citium founded this philosophy, whose core idea is that people should not be swayed by desire or fear. Name this ancient philosophy that, today, is associated with being calm and unemotional.

This country recently experienced a major disruption in its freight rail system, as a labor dispute between two major railway companies and a Teamsters labor union led to a lockout of workers in August 2024. The disruption was caused by a workers' strike which was ended when the national government order arbitration. This nation is the world's second-largest country by total area, known for its vast wilderness and multicultural population. Name this country that is also home to iconic symbols like the maple leaf, the Mounties, and hockey.

In this play, the title character rewrites a letter to send Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to their deaths, and later accidentally stabs Polonius through a tapestry. While the title character of this play duels using poisoned tipped swords with Laertes, he kills King Claudius to complete his revenge for the death of his father. Name this Shakespearean tragedy about the title prince of Denmark, who wonders, "to be, or not to be."
answers: The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark

question: This state's namesake university was founded as a secular school in response to weak leadership at the College of William and Mary. The estate of Monticello was built in this state by one of the eight US presidents to have been born in it. Name this largest of the thirteen original colonies, where Thomas Jefferson was once governor in Richmond.

During this war, opposing generals James Wolfe and Louis-Joseph de Montcalm were each killed at the Battle of the Plains of Abraham in Quebec. Fort Necessity was led, and lost, by George Washington at the outset of this war. The 1763 Treaty of Paris gave Canada to the British and ended what war that pitted the British and their American colonies against two namesake allies?

This athlete ventured into boxing in 2017, facing Floyd Mayweather Jr. in a highly publicized match. Outside the ring, he's known for his flamboyant personality, brash trash talk, and successful whiskey brand, Proper No. Twelve. He holds the distinction of being the first UFC fighter to simultaneously hold titles in two weight classes, featherweight and lightweight. Name this Irish athlete whose lightning-fast 13-second knockout of Jose Aldo in 2015 is still considered one of the most iconic moments in UFC history.

This element is found at the center of an orange solid which was the first human-synthesized metallocene. This element's oxide usually catalyzes the synthesis of ammonia in the Haber-Bosch process. This is the most abundant element found in the inner core of Earth, and exposing it to oxygen gas forms rust. Identify this most common metal on Earth, with atomic number 26 and symbol Fe.

This musician had a long-standing songwriting partnership with Bernie Taupin, which produced numerous chart-topping hits. The artist holds the record for the biggest-selling single of all time with his 1997 tribute to Princess Diana. His flamboyant stage persona, often characterized by extravagant costumes and oversized glasses, became a defining part of his image. His iconic hits like "Rocket Man," "Tiny Dancer," and "Your Song" have resonated with audiences for decades. Who is this legendary musician and performer?

This state's Dutch Harbor is the busiest fishing port in America and a center for the crab industry. This state's city of Nome is the finish line of the yearly Iditarod sled-dog race. The Aleutian Islands, off the west coast of this state, form the southern end of the Bering Sea. Name this state home to Fairbanks, Anchorage, and the capital of Juneau.

This country's province of Mendoza contains the continent's highest peak. The Iguazu River, known for its namesake falls, flows into the Parana River in this country. This country's southern portion contains most of the Patagonia region, and it owns the eastern half of Tierra del Fuego. The northern part of this country is home to plains known as the Pampas, and the Rio de la Plata lies between it and Uruguay. Name this South American country with capital Buenos Aires.

Brothers with this surname host the podcast titled "New Heights" which is rumored to have earned them a deal around $100 million from Amazon's podcasting arm. Their podcast delves into their experiences in the NFL where they made history in 2023 as the first brothers to face each other in a Super Bowl, with one playing for the Kansas City Chiefs and the other for the Philadelphia Eagles. What is the last name of these brothers, one of who retired as the center of the Eagles and the other who dates Taylor Swift.

This actor's refusal to accept his Academy Award for Best Actor in 1973, sending Sacheen Littlefeather in his place, remains a significant moment in Oscar history. He gained early recognition for his powerful performance as Stanley Kowalski in the 1951 film adaptation of "A Streetcar Named Desire." His iconic portrayal of Vito Corleone in "The Godfather" solidified his status as a legendary actor.  He also delivered a memorable performance as Colonel Kurtz in the 1979 war epic "Apocalypse Now." Who is this actor, known for his method acting?

In standard units, this force's namesake constant equals 6.67 times ten to the negative eleventh power. This force's magnitude is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two objects. On earth it causes objects to accelerate at 9.81 meters per second squared. It acts more strongly on objects of greater mass. Name this fundamental force that causes objects to fall to the ground.

A French king with this first name issued the Edict of Nantes, granting religious tolerance to the Huguenots. The first two kings of England's Tudor dynasty both had this name. One king of this name executed Thomas Cromwell and founded the Church of England after the Pope did not allow his divorce from Catherine of Aragon. Give this name of many English kings, the 8th of which married six wives.

This actor recently finalized his divorce from singer and actress Jennifer Lopez after a two-year marriage. He is a dedicated philanthropist and co-founder of the Eastern Congo Initiative, focused on improving the lives of Congolese people. He has also directed critically acclaimed films, such as "The Town" and "Argo," the latter of which won the Academy Award for Best Picture. Earlier in his career, he was part of a dynamic duo with Matt Damon, with whom he co-wrote and starred in the Oscar-winning screenplay for "Good Will Hunting." Who is this Hollywood star?

One event in this religion's history was the Five Pecks of Rice Rebellion, which was led by a "Celestial Master." One important analogy to this religion is the idea that followers abide in this system the way a fish abides in water. In a legend of this religion, the creator god Pangu holds up the sky for eighteen thousand years. Concepts in this religion include ming and wu wei, which are "clarity" and "effortless action." Identify this religion, whose principal text is the Tao Te Ching, which was written by Lao-Tzu, and features the concepts of yin and yang.

During this war, the Battle of Bladensburg allowed the capture of one side's capital. The bloodiest battle of this war was Lundy's Lane. Northern Federalists discussed succession at the Hartford Convention during this war. Events during this war include Oliver Hazard Perry's victory at Lake Erie, Andrew Jackson winning at New Orleans after the official end of the war, and the burning of the White House. Ending with the Treaty of Ghent, name this "second war of independence," fought between American and British forces.

A Holmes dissent claimed this document "does not enact Mr. Herbert Spencer's Social Statics," and legal incorporation uses this amendment to bind states to upholding the Bill of Rights. It removed the Three-Fifths Compromise, and its Privileges and Immunities and Due Process clauses limit states' ability to legislate against their citizens. Name this post-Civil War amendment which grants birthright citizenship and contains the Equal Protection clause.
answers: Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution

question: This gemstone recently made headlines when the second-largest gem-quality specimen ever discovered was unearthed in Botswana. It is composed entirely of carbon atoms arranged in a tightly-packed crystal lattice, contributing to its unparalleled strength. Its high refractive index creates its characteristic sparkle, while its rarity and enduring beauty make it a prized possession and symbol of love and commitment. What is this precious stone renowned for its exceptional hardness and brilliance?

Walter Pitman argued that the Biblical flood myth could have originated from a rapid rise in sea level of this body of water. This body of water connects to the Sea of Marmara through the Bosphorus, right next to the city of Istanbul. The city of Sevastopol lies on the shores of this body of water on the Crimean Peninsula. What sea lies south of Ukraine and north of Turkey, possibly named for the dark shadows its storms cast over the water?

This leader ended an invasion shortly after the head of his brother, Hasdrubal, was thrown into his camp. This man ravaged the Italian countryside for over a decade but was defeated at Zama by Scipio Africanus, ending the Second Punic War. Name this Carthaginian general who led a military force, including elephants, over the Alps.

This movie's memorable score includes the song "The Power of Love" by Huey Lewis and the News. Its sequels explore further adventures in time, including a trip to the futuristic year 2015 and a Wild West escapade in 1885. The film's central plot revolves around Marty McFly's accidental journey to 1955, where he inadvertently disrupts his parents' first meeting and must ensure they fall in love to preserve his own existence. What is the name of this beloved trilogy featuring a time travelling DeLorean?

This track athlete captured the world's attention at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, winning three gold medals and one silver. Tragically, she passed away in her sleep at the young age of 38 due to an epileptic seizure. Her world records in the 100-meter and 200-meter sprints, set in 1988, remain unbroken to this day, solidifying her legacy as the fastest woman of all time. Who was this sprinting legend, affectionately known as "Flo-Jo"?

In a novel by this author, a note written by Arne Saknussemm can be read in a mirror, and is used by Professor Lidenbrock to help find a route into a volcano in western Iceland. In another novel by this author, Ned Land and Pierre Aronnax are shown the secrets of a submarine called the Nautilus by Captain Nemo. Name this French author of Journey to the Center of the Earth and Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.

In bacteria, operons regulate the synthesis of a polycistronic type of this molecule, while a different type oversees the removal of introns and splicing of exons during transcription. One type of this molecule is cloverleaf-shaped, and carries amino acids for translation. Instead of thymine, this molecule contains uracil. Name this single-stranded molecule, which comes in "messenger" and "transfer" types, as opposed to DNA.

These locations are the home of a group of organisms whose species include the "staghorn" and "elkhorn." The Great Blue Hole can be found within one of these locations, named after the country of Belize. The largest of the "barrier" type of these locations is located off the coast of Queensland, Australia. Name these complex marine ecosystems, which primarily consist of the namesake cnidarians.

This probability distribution's characteristics are revealed through a linear Q-Q plot. The 68-95-99.7 rule approximates standard deviations from its mean, used to calculate Z-scores. According to the Central Limit Theorem, the distribution of sample means converges towards this distribution. What is this bell-shaped distribution, also called the Gaussian distribution?

This Nordic nation recently experienced its sixth volcanic eruption in the Reykjanes Peninsula since December 2023, with the latest one starting on August 22, 2024. It is home to Europe's largest glacier, Vatnajökull, and the mesmerizing aurora borealis, or Northern Lights. What is the name of this island country, led from Reykjavík, often called the "Land of Fire and Ice"?

This actor's powerful performance in the 2016 film "Fences," which he also directed, earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor. He began his acting career in theater, gaining recognition for his role in the off-Broadway production of "A Soldier's Play." His breakout film role came in 1989's "Glory," where he portrayed a defiant Civil War soldier, earning him his first Oscar for Best Supporting Actor. Name this actor who also starred in iconic films like "Malcolm X," "Training Day," and "American Gangster," further cementing his status as a Hollywood legend.

The Men's T20 World Cup for this sport was co-hosted by the United States and won by India. This sport's unique terminology includes terms like "googly," a type of delivery that spins in the opposite direction of what the batsman expects, and "silly point," a close-in fielding position near the batsman. Its matches can span multiple days, with the longest format lasting up to five days, testing players' endurance and strategic prowess. What is this bat-and-ball game, beloved by millions worldwide, especially in countries like India, Australia, and England?

While fighting in this war, Armin Tamzarian steals the identity of Seymour Skinner in The Simpsons. After returning home from this war, Frank Castle's family is murdered by the Mafia, which causes him to become The Punisher. The song "Fortunate Son" plays as helicopters transport Bubba Blue and Forrest Gump into this war. The 2017 film The Post details the release of the Pentagon Papers during what war that the United States escalated in the 1960s and 70s?

In one quest, this figure is directed to the ferryman Urshanabi by Siduri. After his companion dies, this figure visits Utnapishtim, who tells him where to find a plant capable of restoring youth. That plant is later stolen by a serpent. This figure slew the guardian of the cedar forest, Humbaba, and the Bull of Heaven, with Enkidu. Name this king of Uruk and hero of a Mesopotamian epic.

This city's men formed a council called the boule, whose makeup was adjusted by Solon. Cleisthenes reformed this city's constitution in 508 BCE, and may have introduced the process of ostracism to this city. Draco created a strict law code for this city, where trials were held on the Areopagus, in the shadow of the Acropolis. Name this city, often considered the birthplace of democracy, which was briefly ruled by thirty tyrants after it was conquered by its ancient rival, Sparta.

BepiColombo is a mission that is set to send a satellite to this planet by 2025. This planet is tidally locked with the Sun in a 3:2 spin-orbit resonance and features the Caloris basin. This planet that was visited by the Messenger spacecraft is the second hottest planet in the solar system and, like the hottest planet Venus, it has no moons. This rocky planet is the smallest in the solar system. Name this closest planet to the sun.

At the Battle of Vosges, this man defeated the Suebi forces led by Ariovistus. At the Battle of Alesia, he defeated Vercingetorix, as described in his Commentaries on the Gallic War, and, at the Battle of Pharsalus, he defeated Pompey the Great. This man also started the Roman Civil War by crossing the Rubicon. Name this Roman statesman who, with Crassus and Pompey, formed the First Triumvirate and was assassinated by Cassius and Brutus on the Ides of March.

This country recently faced a nationwide strike by doctors and nurses, after a doctor was abused and murdered in the eastern city of Kolkata. This nation is also the birthplace of yoga and Ayurveda, ancient practices that promote physical and mental well-being. Additionally, it is known for its rich tapestry of languages, with Hindi and English serving as official languages, and over 19,500 other languages spoken across the country. What is this country, home to Bollywood?

A letter to Trump which addressed the Chinese sale of opioids was written by Rob Portman, a senator of this state. In the 2016 presidential election, one candidate who governed this state dropped out a day after Ted Cruz. The 2016 Republican National Convention was held in this state, whose governor John Kasich refused to attend. Name this state home to cities such as Cincinnati and Columbus, its capital.

This band's final studio album, "In Utero," released in 1993, showcased a rawer and more experimental side of the band. Their breakthrough album, "Nevermind," released in 1991, catapulted them to global fame, with the single "Smells Like Teen Spirit" becoming an anthem for a generation. Their iconic smiley face logo, designed by Kurt Cobain himself, has become a symbol of grunge culture. Which band is this, whose frontman, Kurt Cobain, tragically died in 1994, leaving behind a profound impact on the music world?

This Major League Baseball team clinched its first World Series championship in 1985, led by iconic players like George Brett and Bret Saberhagen. After a period of rebuilding, they made a triumphant return to the World Series in 2014, ultimately falling short, but redeemed themselves the following year, capturing their second title in 2015. They are known for their iconic powder blue uniforms and a passionate fanbase that weathered the ups and downs of the team's history. What is the name of this team based in Kansas City?

The Calypso Deep is the lowest point in this body of water, and Strait of Bonifacio separates two of its larger islands. This sea contains the Balearic Islands, and the Ebro and Rhone rivers flow into it. This sea is connected to the Black Sea via the Bosphorus Strait and to the Atlantic by way of the Strait of Gibraltar. Extensions of this sea include the Aegean and the Adriatic. Containing the islands of Sardinia and Sicily, this sea forms the coastlines of Libya and Algeria. Identify this large sea sandwiched between north Africa and Europe.

Jehovah's Witnesses say its seventh chapter proves only 144,000 people will reach heaven. Addressed to seven churches of Asia and written by John of Patmos, it involves a third of all vegetation getting destroyed by hail and fire, the opening of seven seals, a seven-headed, ten-horned Beast, and the Whore of Babylon. Name this New Testament book which features the Four Horsemen, a prophecy of Jesus' second coming and the end of the world.
answers: Book of the Revelation of John

question: One trilogy by this author deals with the rise and fall of the Snopes family. Many of his stories unfold in the fictional Yoknapatawpha County, including the complex tale of Thomas Sutpen, relayed to Shreve in "Absalom, Absalom!" In this man's most famous novel, Benjy Compson reminisces about his childhood with Caddy. Name this Southern author of "The Sound and the Fury."

Evidence of an advanced writing system for this civilization was found on a Dholavira signboard containing 26 symbols. The Priest King and Dancing Girl statues were found in one city of this civilization, another of which was the port of Lothal. That city included the "College of Priests" and the "Great Bath." An Aryan invasion is a theoretical cause for the destruction of this civilization that included the cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro. Name this Bronze Age civilization centered around a namesake south Asian river.

Mafia Island lies off the coast of this country, which also contains the Ngorongoro Crater in its north. This country's Gombe National Park was home to Jane Goodall's chimpanzee studies. Three large lakes border this country; one of them, Lake Tanganyika, named the republic that combined with Zanzibar to form this country. Home to Dar es Salaam, name this African country, which contains such landmarks as the Serengeti Plain and Mt. Kilimanjaro.

Sputter coating is used to apply a thin layer of a conducting material for samples used in one form of this technique. This technique comes in transmission and scanning types, both of which utilize a beam of high-speed electrons. This technique was popularized by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek and Robert Hooke, who used it to discover the cell. Name this technique, which uses optical and electron devices to magnify small things.

This Formula One driver tragically suffered a severe head injury in a skiing accident in 2013 and has remained out of the public eye since then. His dominance in the sport was particularly evident during his time with Ferrari. He also shares the record for the most World Drivers' Championship titles with Lewis Hamilton, both having secured seven.  He holds the record for the most consecutive Drivers' Championships, winning five in a row from 2000 to 2004. Who is this iconic German racing driver, often referred to as "Schumi"?

This film features a memorable scene where the protagonist unknowingly starts the Watergate scandal by calling security. It also includes the iconic line, "Life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get," spoken by the title character. The film follows the life of a kind-hearted but slow-witted man from Alabama who unwittingly influences several historical events of the 20th century. Name this movie that won six Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Tom Hanks' portrayal of the title character.

Israel launched what it claimed to preemptive aerial strike against this nation on August 25. This country, renowned for its delectable cuisine, is home to the ancient city of Byblos, one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world. It is also the only country in the Arab world without a desert. Its flag features a cedar tree, symbolizing strength and eternity, on a background of red and white stripes representing sacrifice and peace. Its capital, Beirut, was once known as the "Paris of the Middle East" due to its vibrant culture and cosmopolitan atmosphere. What is the name of this Middle Eastern nation, home to Hezbollah?

The Supreme Court decision in Bradwell v. Illinois proved decisive in this person's trial, which was rescheduled because she was accused of jury tampering. While she was found guilty, she never paid the one thousand dollar fine for casting an illegal ballot. She met Elizabeth Cady Stanton at Seneca Falls, and died fourteen years after her goal was achieved. Name this suffragist, pictured on the U.S. dollar coin from 1979 to 1981.

Rulers of this country used turtle shells as prophetic "oracle bones" to learn of their future. The "tribute system" involved foreign messengers bowing to the ruler of this modern-day country, who was justified by the "Mandate of Heaven." A "terracotta army" protects the tomb of Shi Huangdi, an ancient ruler of this country. The Shang and Qin dynasties ruled what country home to a massive "Great Wall?"

This man, who appointed Shirley Hufstedler as the first Secretary of Education, was once attacked by a rabbit while fishing. He argued for energy diversification and conservation in a speech now known as the "malaise" speech, and the Iranian hostage crisis ended on his last day in office. The negotiator of the Camp David Accords and winner of the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize name this US President, an active supporter of Habitat for Humanity.

This bird species recently lost one of its most famous members, Sphen, who captured hearts worldwide with his same-sex partnership and devoted parenting at the Sea Life Sydney Aquarium. These birds are highly adapted to life in the Southern Hemisphere, with dense feathers providing insulation, flippers for swimming, and webbed feet for paddling. Their colonies can range from a few dozen to tens of thousands of individuals, creating bustling communities on rocky shores and ice floes. What is this iconic bird, known for its distinctive black and white plumage and waddling gait?

This phenomenon is described by the code GR in the METAR system. The magnitude of this phenomenon can be predicted with Vertical Integrated Liquid Density, which measures both the moisture content of a cloud and the strength of its updrafts. This phenomenon is caused when water droplets are blown upward, where cold air freezes them, before falling to the ground. Name this type of precipitation consisting of balls of ice.

This athlete's impressive career batting average of .311 over ten seasons with the Brooklyn Dodgers showcased his talent and resilience. He was awarded the inaugural Rookie of the Year Award in 1947. His number, 42, was retired across Major League Baseball in 1997, a testament to his enduring legacy.
